CANADA
Ottawa,
July 3, 1941.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 26th ultimo you may expend an amount of $8.00 in the purchase of wool for the handicraft classes at the Koksilah School. When forwarding the account you should mark on it -- "Pay from B.C. Special".

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent,
Duncan, B.C.
Sir:

Enclosed herewith you will find Requisition, in duplicate, on Form No.37, from Miss Sadie Dougall, teacher of the Koksilah Indian Day School, covering the purchase of 20 lbs of white wool and 5 lbs of Black wool, to be used in connection with the handicraft classes at the school under her charge.

Your obedient servant,

[R. H. Moore]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA

Dear Sir:

Please find attached requisition in duplicate for material required by the teacher of the Koksilah Indian Day School for Manual Training purposes. Trusting that this requisition will be approved in due time.

Vancouver, B.C.

To the Secretary of the Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter No. 343016, dated Feb 8th, in which you say that the Department will be glad to hear from me in regard to several matters relating to Indian Schools.

Will you allow me to say first of all that the Government's long delay in giving a decided answer to the Indians in regard to the land question is having a most disastrous effect upon our educational and religious work among the Indians. Our Church of England missionaries in this Diocese of Caledonia (Northern B.C.) have steadily counselled the Indians to be law abiding. In consequence of this the Indians say that we are servants of the Government trying to get their land from them. Our Indians have been stirred up by agitators. They have been asked to raise a large sum of money to carry their case to the Privy Council. Money is being freely given for this purpose. Our Missionaries held aloof from this telling the Indians that if they will only wait patiently the Dominion Government will see that they are treated fairly. Not very long ago Indian delegates from all parts assembled at Vancouver to arrange to carry their claims to England. I think the Department should inquire who presided at this meeting. I am informed that it was an official of the Indian Department. Since then the attitude of our Indians towards our missionaries is more marked. Our missionaries are loyal to those in authority while at the same time telling the Indians what will be best for them in the end.

To give a specific example of what I mean:

Our Nassett Indians were not in the least agitated about the land question, they were quite contented in mind until they received a letter from Rev. Mr. Tait a Methodist missionary.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6401, File 827-1, part 1)
missionary more than 500 miles away. He and the Rev. A. E. Green seem to be the chief movers in this matter. Rev. A. E. O'Meara, Church of England, does not belong to this diocese, and has no authority from me. No doubt some of our missionaries think that the question of the Indian Title should be authoritatively settled but as a body we hold that the Indians being wards of the Dominion Government, this Government should have the question settled without this most unwise stirring up of the Indian mind. This is by way of introduction to what I have to report.

1. With great difficulty and at much expense I secured a male teacher for Gitladamiks, the uppermost Indian village on the Nass river. Mr. R. J. George, has an expert knowledge of gardening and farming & has an earnest desire to show the Indians of this village how to cultivate their rich lands. Accompanied by Archdeacon Collison, who knows the language so well, I took him up the river last summer and introduced him assuring the people that he was not after their land, but only wished to teach them and do them good. They received him most kindly until the delegate from this land conference returned returned from Vancouver. Now Mr. George writes me as follows-

"At a Council meeting at Gitladamiks to consider the matter of setting apart a piece of land for the Mission house they were so undecided that they came to no decision. I enquired the cause and was told that they considered me the thin edge of the wedge. The summed up the situation thus. The Bishop the Archdeacon, Mr. McCullagh and myself are the servants of the Government and are seeking to deprive them of their land. Seeing that I am regarded as a traitor by them I have concluded after prayerful consideration that the only thing for me to do is to leave the river".

Mr. A. F. Seath, our school teacher at Lakkalzap on the same river, writes by the same mail in much the same strain. I shall endeavour to persuade these men to hold on, but you will see how this land agitation is upsetting all our work. The feeling up the Skeena has been intense but is a little
new. Our Missionaries urged the Indians to wait patiently till the Commissioner came from Ottawa. He came but only to repeat the same message which had so often been given before.

"I will report to Ottawa all you have to say." The Indians have great respect for authority. All that is needed is a decided answer.

2. In regard to Nassett a new industry has developed at North Island, a Fishing Company is erecting a station there with a steamer carrying fish to Prince Rupert. In consequence of this large numbers of the Nassett people have gone from the village. What Rev. Mr. Hogan recommends is that Miss Benshaw should continue teaching the little ones at Nassett and that Mr. Sherwood should follow the bigger children to North Island and teach school there.

If the Department will make a grant of rough lumber 3,000 ft at $17.50 per thousand with shingles &c the natives will put a building up 30 x 20 with a "lean to" at back for teacher to live in.

I wrote about this to the Indians Agent, Queen Charlotte Islands, but as Mr. Perry was leaving about that time the letter may be waiting for the new agent, whoever he may be, to arrive. I hope the department will make this small grant. It will be seen from this that owing to this new move on the part of so many of the people the question of tents must be deferred for another year. This will show the Department what we have to contend with in trying to carry out any plan.

3. I asked Mr. Fuller the carpenter to whom I referred in my previous letter if he would undertake the work of teaching the Indian young men & older boys carpentry but he sees too good an opportunity for work in Prince Rupert to accept such a position. I think that this is a matter that the Indian Agent should take in hand.

Let me say in closing that I fully appreciate the difficulty in connection with the Indian Title and the dispute between the two Governments but there is no denying the fact
that our whole Indian work is suffering because of the lack of a decisive answer from those who represent "The King"

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

(signed) F. H. Du Vernet

Sir:-

(Lach-kalsap, Naas River.)

I saw Mr Albert Smeath (a single man forty six years of age), who was alone in the Village, awaiting the return of the Indians. He had been sent by his Lordship Bishop DuVernet, as missionary and teacher to the Indians. He has never taught school before. In reference to the request of the Bishop for a grant of $500.00 per annum for Mr Smeath, at the present time I am not in a position to recommend such a grant, as he had not yet opened the school, and is without experience. After he has been in the work some time, it will be seen whether he is qualified or not.

This school can only be kept open for six months of the year as the Indians move to Fishery Bay early in March to fish the oolichans, returning in May for three weeks or so to make gardens and in June go to the salmon canneries till the end of September.

I would recommend that the grant be at the rate of $400.00 per annum for balance of year ending March 31st 1910, and if Mr Smeath proves to be a successful teacher, the grant be $500.00 per annum, commencing April 1st 1910.

Sir,

I beg to request you to be good enough to peruse the enclosed letter received from Mr. Alexander Stone, of Lake Kelso, which will give you an idea of the manner in which many of the Indians on the Mississagi River are disposed to treat the missionaries who labour among them. Timothy Derrick is from England, Anna the wife, Peter Cogdon, William Fox, John, etc., are from Lake Kelso and Minden. These men are very civil and polite whenever I appear on the scene, but from time to time very discouraging and bad reports are received at this office, and I am led personally over anxious to take these people into account, certain information of a serious nature is held before me.

You will learn from the personal of the letter that the School at Lake Kelso was closed during the last quarter because the missionary...
followed him persistently without any obstruction from him, when he intended to take up teaching, but was prevented from doing so by the opposition of a few agitators who influenced the people against him.

The enclosed are my returns for the quarter. I beg to say that I shall not be again able to continue School this summer. There are certain points relative to these returns that need explaining.

(1.) Conduct & Class Standing: It is quite impossible to remark on a large percentage of the children because I so seldom saw them that only their names are familiar to me.

(2.) The same applies to remarks on progress etc.

(3.) You will notice I have stated the school was open 65 days but that 12 holidays occurred. These were due (1) 1 day to the school store and chimney being in such a condition that the whole school was smoked out, and I had to close for repairs. (2) 1 day because of the funeral of a chief and the impossibility of opening the school without violating public feeling.

(3.) The next two half days. (A) Because of a general move to Kincolith of half the people, and though I rang for school, no one came. (B) One afternoon all the children kept away after recess time.

(4.) The other days were due to the departure to Fisher Bay.

Here I had no school, no materials, nothing. I want to use an old
house, but it ought for the second time I lighted the stove, and
it was not until the second week that I could make it habitable
and safe and get the children together.
I could, even then, do nothing but oral work, without slates, or
books. However I managed to teach English, scripture and mental
Arithmetic and spelling, (by means of a piece of charcoal on a white
board.) But this so limited the possibilities of work that I had to
confine myself to half a day every day. Apart, excepting on the
first two days, not a single Lakhkalsap child came to school. I have
very good reason to think that the parents deliberately withheld
the little ones, not busy fishing more to their harm than mine—
But my duty, as a good Englishman, was to keep that
school open if I could. School requisites or no school
requisites; and I invited every Kincolith, Dance and Lindertes
parent at Fishery Bay, at their request, to send their little

ending; and am of opinion that these outside children, by their
regularity, learnt more in two weeks than the average Lakhkalsap
child had learnt of the English language in two months. Thus, I

morning, and every Lakhkalsap child had an opportunity of schooling
throughout that time; and I conscientiously entered them "absent," as

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 18th Inst. addressed to me as the Head of the Anglican Church in Northern British Columbia. In this letter you say in justification of your interfering in strictly Church matters in our Anglican Mission of Lakkalzap: "The position which I take in the matter, and as long as I am an official of the Indian Department having the interests of the Indians at heart, is that the matter of Indian missions is as much my concern as it is yours. If your Church is not able to supply that village with an ordained clergyman, I deem it my business to see that the Indians' requirements are met; and this with a view to improving the present apparently disastrous conditions on the Naas River with which your Church does not appear to have been in a position to cope."

As Head of the Anglican Church in Northern British Columbia I wish to take the strongest possible exception to two points enunciated here by you.

(1) In the first place your assumption of authority over purely Church matters cannot be allowed to pass unchallenged. Whether the Anglican Church deems it best to have an ordained missionary or an unordained missionary to impart religious instruction in an Indian Mission belonging to this Church is a matter entirely outside your province as an official of the State, for the simple reason that the State does not undertake to impart religious instruction to the Indians, nor to provide in any way for such religious teaching.

Our Indian Committee has gone fully into the question of what is the best way to minister to the religious needs of the Indians on the Naas River, numbering all told not more than about seven hundred and distributed among five or six small villages. We decided some time ago that it would be an unjustified expenditure of men and money to attempt to have an ordained white missionary in every small village. The Venerable Archdeacon Collison has been about thirty years on the Lower Naas, and the Rev. J.B. Cullagh about the same length, on the Upper Naas. With two such experienced missionaries as these, both talking the language and understanding the native character supervising, and certain lay missionaries, and native catechists assisting, we decided as a Church that the religious needs of the seven hundred Nishgas on the Naas would be amply met.

In the case of Lakkalzap, as the village is deserted in the summer time all the Indians being at the canneries at the mouth of the river where Archdeacon Collison and a paid native catechist ministers to them, when the lay worker resigned in the spring, we did not deem it necessary to put into operation our present satisfactory plan until the autumn.

It is not the business of the Indian Agent to interfere in purely Church matters we felt under no obligation to inform you of our plans. As you have not set foot in Lakkalzap since last May, over six months, and I have just returned from there I am in a position to emphatically
denied statements you very recently forwarded to the Department to the following effect, quoting your own words, "The Indians are most insistent upon having a Methodist missionary to take charge of their mission and school" and "The Indians are dissatisfied with the Church of England".

There is one disgruntled Indian, Charlie Russ, the only avowed Methodist Indian on the Naas River, but he does not live at Lakkalazap but in a house by himself six miles down the river. Ever since we took the Mission over—eight years ago—paying the Methodist Church for their buildings and good will and receiving a solemn pledge that they would not attempt to enter the field again, this disgruntled Indian has been a mischief maker consistently sending reports to the Methodists at Fort Simpson that the Lakkalazap people were dissatisfied with the Church of England. It is to be regretted that when you and the Rev. A.E. Green visited Lakkalazap last May you took for your guide and counsellor this same Charlie Russ. I was informed when at Lakkalazap that it was Mr. Green who told some of the Indians there that the Methodist Church was willing to send them an ordained missionary, taking advantage of the temporary vacancy in our Mission.

In the occasion of this visit, in the absence of our missionary and without any permission or authority you and Mr. Green, Indian School Inspector, forced your way into our Mission House which does not stand on the Indian Reserve, and reported adversely, the Department having no jurisdiction whatsoever over Church property.

The point upon which I am asking, through our Member of Parliament, for a ruling from the Minister of the Interior is this—Has an Indian Agent authority to hold this threat over the head of a Bishop of the Church of England regarding the ordination of a missionary in regard to such a strictly Church matter as to whether there shall be an ordained or an unordained missionary to impart religious teaching in an Anglican Mission? If your Church is not able to supply that village with an ordained clergyman I deem it MY BUSINESS to see that the Indians' requirements are met".

(2) In the second place on behalf of the Anglican Church I resent most warmly the implication contained in your words—"The present apparently disastrous conditions on the Naas River with which your Church does not appear to have been in a position to cope".

After consultation with our veteran missionaries on the Naas I have come to the conclusion that by "Disastrous conditions" you must refer to the manufacture manufacture of intoxicating drink by some of the Indians on the Upper Naas and the consequent amount of drinking.

The enforcing of Law and Order is not the function of the Church but of the State. It is not the duty of an ordained missionary to act as either a magistrate or constable. Any attempt to do so must lessen his influence over the Indians in religious matters.

On Indian Reserves it is the duty of the Indian Agent and Dominion Constable to see that Law and Order are maintained, and that the manufacture and distribution of intoxicating liquor is stopped.

As the Upper Naas is a difficult region to reach it has been the lack of proper supervision on the part of the Indian Agent of the Naas Agency and the lack of proper enforcement of the law by the State that has led...
to what you are pleased to term "the disastrous conditions on the Naas River". This is a matter with which only the strong arm of the Law can "cope". Knowing the noble work that the Rev. J. B. McCullagh has done on the Upper Naas, and the most trying and dangerous position he has filled for many years I most warmly resent your charge that the Anglican Church has not been able to "cope" with certain conditions requiring the enforcement of Law and Order and therefore you have given the Department of Indian Affairs your "opinion" that the time has arrived to "transfer this Mission from the Church of England to the Methodist Church", also informing the Department that "The Methodist authorities have expressed their willingness to supply the mission with an ordained clergyman". Sir,

I beg to inform you that the Lord Bishop of Caledonia has written to me a letter by which I judge that he is incensed through the receipt of a letter from the Department regarding the transfer of the Lak-kalzap Indian mission to the Methodist Church. The Department's letter to him is quoted in full.

Had I not been given assurance by some of the Bishop's clergy who know the conditions at Lak-kalzap well, that His Lordship would likely be favourably disposed to this transfer if properly approached thereon, I might have allowed a strong reluctance in the matter of negotiating this proposal to have dominated my position.

I must call attention to the fact that I did not inform the Department that the Methodist authorities would be "pleased" to send a teacher to Lak-kalzap, as mentioned in the Department's letter to the Bishop. What I did say was that the Methodist Church had expressed willingness to provide an ordained clergyman, and that if a transfer of the Mission were made, the Church may be able to provide a teacher also; and this subject to a satisfactory arrangement being made having the approval of all parties.

I regret that the Department, when writing to the Bishop did not make clear my position as set forth in my letter of October 4th last. In that letter I stated that, whilst desirous to draw the Department's attention to all the facts concerning Lak-kalzap, I did not feel in a position to advise the Department what step it was best to take in the matter, but that I was of opinion that negotiations having in view the transfer of the mission to the Methodist Church would be most effectual. Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of Oct. 23rd, in which you say:

I wish to enter a most emphatic protest against the way the Rev. A.E. Green, Methodist minister and Indian School Inspector, has again and again, especially on the Naas River used his position as a Government officer to further the interests of the Methodist Church against those of the Church of England. Mr. G.G. Perry, who was a probationary Methodist minister before his appointment as Indian Agent, has up to now endeavoured to be impartial, but in this case he has most certainly overstepped the mark in suggesting the transfer of a Church of England Mission to the Methodist Church. We have an ordained clergyman at Lakkalsap and I shall take vigorous steps if there is any interference with our Mission there on the part of any Government official.

The Church of England was first by many years on the Naas River and founded a Mission at the mouth of the river and a Mission at the head of navigation on the upper river, 65 miles up. These Missions are Kincolith and Rev. J.B. McCullagh has been 30 years on the Upper Naas and Archdeacon..."
Collins over 30 years at Kincolith, succeeding another Church of England Missionary who was there some years before.

The Methodists founded a Mission at Lakkalsap 25 miles up from Kincolith as Rev. A.M. Green was the founder; the village is sometimes called "Greenville". More than half the native Christians at Lakkalsap were baptized in the Church of England having either come up from Kincolith or down from our Upper Mission. The Methodist Church had great difficulty with this Mission. There were thirteen different missionaries in about the same number of years. Natives disciplined by our Church went off to the Methodist Church and vice versa. For three years there was no missionary there, and the Indians asked to be taken over by our Church. After long negotiations with Dr. Whittington, the Superintendent of Methodist Missions, we paid $1,500 for the old rotten buildings, and the good will of the Methodist Church, Dr. Whittington giving his pledge that the Methodist Church would not attempt to re-enter the field. Rev. A.M. Green never approved of this transfer. One can understand his feeling and I have tried to make allowances, but every time he has visited the Naas river at Kincolith, Lakkalsap, Gwinoha, Aiyanash, and Gittadamiks he has worked against the Church of England. Our missionaries have traced back dissatisfaction to him again and again, and I am determined to put a stop to this.

Probably because of the many changes Lakkalsap is the most difficult Mission we have to deal with. The natives make the life of a missionary there intolerable. They are the most insolent Indians I have ever met. They tell me they won't have this man, or that man. When our missionary was teacher and catechist combined, they threw it in my face that he was not a missionary because he was paid by Government. In vain I pointed out that only part of
his salary came from the Government. It is firmly fixed in their mind that
the school teacher is paid by the Government. This is one of the reasons
why our Mission Board decided that it was best for the Government to
appoint the teacher. We never expected that the Indian Agent would suggest
to the Department that our Mission be handed over to the Methodist Church
and further volunteer the information, which is manifestly outside his
official duty as an agent of the Government, that the Methodist Church
would supply a teacher.

Rev. A.E. Green, in his capacity of Indian School Inspector, told the
chiefs of Gitladaemiks which is part of our Upper Naas Mission that it was
not necessary for them to have a Church of England teacher, for the
Government would send them one. We have no objection to this if the Govern-

using a Government position to favour the Methodist cause I shall appeal
to our member of Parliament to rectify this injustice.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

School was closed on date of visit. I was accompanied by Mr. Inspector Tyson.

The matter of a school teacher was dealt with in a public meeting with the Indians held the same day.

Whilst I was not enthusiastic over this proposal, I agreed that such an arrangement might be tried as an experiment. The two inspectors agreed to deal further with the matter. I beg to submit for the Department's approval, the application of Miss Alice E. Hannam for the position of school teacher for the Lakgalzap Indian Day school. Miss Hannam holds a temporary certificate for B.C. and her application has been recommended by Mr. Gairns, Inspector of Indian Schools and also by the Rev. G. H. Raley, Principal of the Coqualeetza Institute who has given her an excellent testimonial.

I would recommend Miss Hannam's appointment at the usual salary of $900.00 per annum and bonus as allowed to teachers of Indian schools, also fuel and light. As there is no teacher's residence at Lakgalzap, Miss Hannam will have to pay $5.00 per month out of her salary as rent for the use of the mission house. Arrangements to this end have been made with Archbishop Du Vernet who has informed me the mission house will be available until such time as a missionary is sent to take charge of Lakgalzap. Owing to the isolation of this village during the winter months, I almost hesitated to accept Miss Hannam's application as I believed the isolation would prove most trying as there are no other white people in the vicinity. However as Miss Hannam is to be accompanied by her niece (15 years) she will not be entirely by herself.
Owing to heavy travelling expenses for herself and her niece from Vancouver to Lakgalzap Miss Hannam has requested an advance of $100.00 on her salary. The Lekgalsap School, I regret to say is still without a teacher notwithstanding the efforts which are being made to secure the services of a suitable person to take up the work. The former school teacher and field matron at Lekgalsap, Miss Burgess and Miss Copper, received $900.00 each per annum with bonus and also free light and fuel. If the same service and efficiency are to be expected from a man and wife undertaking the duties of school teacher and matron, I am of the opinion that the wife, as field matron should receive a higher remuneration than $300.00 per annum. The combined salary at present offered in the case of man and wife amounts to $850.00 per annum including the bonus. There is the possibility of the bonus being discontinued, in which event the salary would be only $850.00 per annum.

If I may be permitted to do so, I would suggest to the Department that in the case of man and wife taking up the work of school teacher and field matron respectively, the wife giving satisfactory service as matron, that the salary be fixed at $1500.00 per annum.

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 23rd October enclosing copy of a communication from L. Douglas, of Greenville, Nass River, relative to engaging the services of Mr. R.S. Woods to teach a night class in the village. In reply I beg to say that this matter was taken up with me by the Indians during a recent visit to Greenville in September.

Owing to circumstances, I declined to give my consent at the time, but not wishing to be thought arbitrary in the matter I suggested that they refer it to the Department at Ottawa.

In August last year, Woods got into trouble at Kincolith, by supplying liquor to an Indian named Hubert Haldane. Haldane was found drowned shortly afterwards, and it is supposed that in a state of intoxication following the drinking bout he accidentally fell overboard from his boat which was moored to the Kincolith Wharf.

Serious trouble followed as Haldane's relations demanded blood money from Woods. Woods was tried and fined $300.00, or in default of payment, to be imprisoned for six months. In addition, he was ordered to leave Kincolith reserve.

Woods is a half breed, whose mother, also a breed, belongs to the Kincolith band, but at present is living with a half breed named Billy Madden, who spends most of his time at Ketchikan, Alaska.
Woods is an intelligent fellow, having received a fair education. He has visited Ottawa on one or two occasions in the capacity of interpreter for Indian land delegations from the Nass River.

Personally, I have nothing against Woods whom I have known for many years, and do not wish to keep in remembrance an unfortunate mix-up which I know he has often regretted. Any action taken has been in his own interests, and he has frequently been told that he is far better away from an Indian Reserve.

He is a returned soldier, having served overseas, and is married to a white woman whom he met in England.

Whilst I do not altogether place much confidence in the idea of a night class as being the primary reason, I believe the Indians really want him because he has always taken a leading part in village games and entertainments.

At the present time, Woods is holding a good position as freight checker in the C.N.R., freight shed in Prince Rupert, receiving a fairly good salary, and I hardly think he would be ready to give this up for anything so uncertain as that offered by the Indians of Greenville without any satisfactory guarantee that they can pay for his services.

Sir:

Referring to the quarterly return of the Lakalsap (Greenville) Indian Day School and your report for the months of May and June last, it appears that this school is closed during the greater part of May and June in each year, owing to the fact that the Indians remove from the village during that period, being away at the fisheries.

It is considered that, as the Indians are away during the two above mentioned months and do not return until late in September, it would be advisable in future to have the school conducted from September 15th to May 15th in each year, a period of 8 months. We have been paying the teacher salary in full for the 10 teaching months when practically only eight months' service is performed. This is, of course, not the fault of the teacher, but entirely owing to the fact that the Indians are away from the village. I shall be pleased to have your opinion as to whether you would concur in the above suggestion. We are aware of the difficulty in obtaining the services of a teacher for this isolated point, and it may be that it would not be possible to obtain the services of a teacher for 8 months only in each year. In our letter of the 17th ultimo, you were requested to obtain the services of a married teacher for this school, and if such is secured it might be necessary to retain his services for the full year. Our suggestion that the school be kept open only eight months is in order to keep the cost of conducting this school as low as possible. However, we will await your views in the matter and also what arrangements you have been able to make to obtain a suitable married teacher.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have the honour to forward herewith my Monthly Report for January 1926.

Owing to having received a letter from the Greenville Village Council requesting me to attend a meeting at Greenville which had been called by Miss A. M. Hannam, day school teacher, on Monday 4th January, and also received a letter from the lady herself asking me to go up there as soon as possible, I left for Greenville on Sunday, 3rd January.

The meeting was held as arranged and was attended by a full muster of the council, also by Sam McKay who had claimed that he had been appointed "school trustee" by the Indian Agent. Miss Hannam's complaint was that she had been publicly insulted by the Indians at a Christmas gathering and that she had been annoyed by Sam McKay attending the school during school hours and interfering with her teaching. Through Johnson Ross, interpreter, I was told that the Indians had not meant to insult her and were sorry if Miss Hannam had taken it that way. Miss Hannam accepted the explanation and there was thus no need for me to take any further action in this connection. I then told the council that Sam McKay had no authority to interfere with the school and that no trustee was appointed. This led to a general discussion of school matters which I said came under the jurisdiction of the Inspector of Indian schools and could not be dealt with by me. This appointment of a "school trustee" which according to the Indian interpretation really means "school helper" appears to have been provided for under a village by-law introduced about ten years or more ago and as can be readily understood, could be a source of considerable annoyance to a trained white lady teacher. Miss Hannam appears to have had a lot to put up with and was undoubtedly suffering with nervous strain. I smoothed matters out with the council before I left and was asked to send for the school inspector.

S. G. Newnham,
Dominion Constable.

Sir:-

I beg to inform the Department of the resignation of Mr. F. Job as teacher of the Greenville Indian Day School to take effect at the end of the present month.

His resignation is regretted, particularly as he was a very capable teacher and well liked by the Indians. He could not stand the isolation and although he would have liked to remain another winter his health would not permit it.

I am enclosing an application received from Mrs. Isabel Moore, with copies of Inspectors' reports. I would suggest that Mrs. Moore be appointed as field matron as her husband has knowledge of First Aid and could render her assistance in this line.

In view of the extra service which will be of great benefit to the Indians, especially during the winter months when Greenville is cut off from outside medical aid, I would recommend a salary of $1270.00 with the usual allowance of fuel and light as was paid to Miss Hannam, a previous teacher. It is becoming increasingly difficult to obtain teachers for these isolated places, and I believe the salary suggested would be a fair recompense for the position.

Observations on Education

It must be understood throughout the whole of following remarks, opinions and suggestions, that they apply only to my own personal experience of the work of education here among the Indians of the Reserve near on the line, in the most isolated part of the province; because I have had no reference book, and have no knowledge whatever of the practices and characteristics of any other schools of the Indians here or anywhere else, and therefore cannot say what may be best for others than that the general education should be conducted by the best teachers who can be obtained, and that the children should be taught in such a manner as will make them useful members of society.

Returning to the language question. Any intelligent person—no who read this or who wrote it—must admit that if we attended a lecture on hygiene delivered in this distance we should know no more of the subject than if we had closed our eyes; this explains the qualifications in my answer to the query "Is instruction purely religious or hygienic, or directed?" of the next morning.

The point of the paramount importance of English to the native children having been pressed home with sufficient emphasis, I think I ought, as an experienced language teacher, to make some suggestions as to improvements in materials and methods. In a school like this the first center is the most important of all books, the first step toward the acquisition of new words and ideas from the point of view of future usefulness; no body of knowledge would be complete, no education, and nothing that is built upon acquirements would be valuable without a knowledge of the English language.
I have by no means exhausted the ramifications of my subject. I should like to touch on my objections to the "Inclusive Method" of journalism used here, on "Busy Work," or Planning the Indians by sending pupils' work (which is really not done by pupils) to the Prince Rupert or other exhibitions and winning prizes, on the necessity of a change in the Indian attitude to the school; that it should be considered something more than a place dry and warm on chill wet days; a glance at the register of the pupils of today, and to the end of June to call from a pool in a water closet, a really cold wet day, and compare a full house, boys, ready to be used for sale, while outside cold winds whistle through the windows, as to the change demanded.

I should like to say something on the relation of the amount of time in the composition of his lot with that of his environment, realizing much of the world's teaching is done in the same way as the savage does his work, and it is no better teaching. Grades at times, there? Yes, grades, first, fifth, and sixth—there is no such thing as a grade that is not a grade, just where we are going, how far we have come, what we have accomplished, and what we have yet to accomplish. The first part of the year is the hardest, the second part of the year is easier, but the third part of the year is the hardest of all. It has been a most interesting experience here, and this thought apparently, although it seems to be a genuine acquisition of impressions gathered first-hand.

Malcolm Henry

Dear Sir:

The following are some of the changes in the teaching staff of the Indian Schools and certain cases about which there has been some discussion.

I strongly recommend the following:

1. Mr. Norman Green moved from Kitwancool to Kincolith. This was in accord with the wishes of Mr. Green and the Kincolith people. He is one of our most successful teachers.

3. There has been some criticism of Mrs. Bridges at Lakalzap. She at first resigned but later withdrew this. In view of the great scarcity of teachers and of the very fair work she has done, I would suggest that she be left at Lakalzap. She engages to get some female companionship for the coming year.

4. I believe the Inspector urges that two teachers be provided for Aiyansh or as it is sometimes called, Gitlakdamics. There are certainly two teachers needed here. The number of pupils warrants it and there is a house provided for one. Where such an extra teacher can be found I do not know. This year neither the Indian Agent or myself have had any applications from teachers. In case an extra teacher can be found and the Department consents to an appointment at Aiyansh, then my suggestion is that a qualified teacher be sent there as senior teacher and the present teacher, Mr. Kinley, be retained as junior. If a senior teacher is not sent, and I doubt if one can be found, then my suggestion is that Mr. Kinley be again left in charge. He at least
does fair work as a teacher and has many other qualities of a most valuable nature.

All the other teachers with whom I have to deal remain as last year. Mrs. Smiley, of Massett, at first resigned, but has withdrawn her resignation and is ready to stay at Massett.

Dear Sir:

I know you have much knowledge of the Indian Village School situation in Northern B.C. You know also that I am Bishop of Caledonia and that I am therefore intensely interested in these natives' welfare. Owing to the war and the joining up with the forces on the part of many teachers, it has been found impossible to provide teachers for all the schools. In this diocese there are at present three schools without teachers. During the late summer I had two applications: one from a very young girl and at that time I only knew of one school likely to be vacant and as it was extremely isolated I wrote her advising that she would not consider it; later another girl asked for my nomination, but before it could be arranged she got a school in a white section. An experienced teacher asked to be changed from Greenville to Metlakatla. This I advised against as she had been only a year at Greenville and was well liked there, but she then wrote me that she had decided to remain with her mother for the year as her mother was not well.

I tell you all this to show you the difficulty in getting teachers.

Then I consider a great mistake was made in the letting go of the teacher, Mr. Bryant, of Metlakatla who could have been retained. With the real dearth of teachers, everything should have been done to retain this excellent teacher, one of the best in the North.
I have searched everywhere for competent teachers. I have asked the B.C. Indian Office to find them. The only condition desired was that they should be Protestant. The Vancouver Office has been unable to find any. Then I began to suggest the temporary appointment of unqualified but really competent persons.

I suggested Mr. Hayhurst the husband of the teacher at Gitwangak. She had taught at Greenville and he assisted her there in a very efficient manner, besides that he was skilled in the dispensing of drugs. Mr. Hayhurst was willing to go to Greenville and the people were anxious to have him but Mr. Barry, the Indian School Inspector, turned it down. Even when there was no one else in sight. Then it occurred to the Indian Agent and myself that a well educated native could fill the position as a temporary expedient and a young man who had done well at a boarding school, William McKay, was suggested. This person was also acceptable to the people of Greenville, but again Mr. Barry turned it down. The Indian Commissioner sends me the answers to my letters but he always says the matter has been referred to Mr. Barry.

Ever since I have had anything to do with the Indian Schools in this area, I have found the School Inspector a most difficult man to get along with. He offers no co-operation, especially at this time when everyone ought to do everything in his or her power to carry on. It does seem to me that we ought to be able to look to the officials who have as their sacred duty the welfare of the native people for every possible assistance in making the best of an extremely difficult situation. It is a tragedy that these three schools are closed. It will most seriously set the children back in their education. The natives themselves resent what they mightily consider as a neglect of their right.
I am writing directly to you and over the head of the Vancouver Office, for we are quite unable to get reasonable co-operation there. I think Major McKay would co-operate, but with Mr. Barry the case seems hopeless. He seems to search out reasons which justify him in opposing any suggestions made by anyone else.

I can assure you that I am not alone in my objections. May I hope that you will give us the authority to fill vacant schools during the war with any reasonably qualified person so that the children upon whom so much effort has already been spent may not slip back.

Believe me,

Yours faithfully,
Prince Rupert, B.C.
19th November, 1941.

My dear Bishop Rix:

I have for acknowledgment your unsigned letter of November 12, in which you discuss the difficulty experienced by you in securing fully qualified teachers for a number of Indian day schools in your diocese.

It is perhaps inevitable that in a critical period such as this a shortage of qualified teachers should develop and that circumstances may arise whereby we shall be compelled to select the best teaching material available, regardless of professional standing.

The experience of the officials in the Welfare and Training Division, however, has been that with a few rare exceptions the employment of teachers other than those with full professional standing is a sheer waste of public funds.

Indian day and residential schools are, as you know, subjected to very severe criticism from time to time, and I am personally disposed to think that this criticism will increase as tax imposts become more burdensome. You will readily appreciate, therefore, that the greatest care must be exercised by our officials in the selection of teachers and in the general conduct of our educational institutions.

I note that you refer to the case of William McKay, a native, who might have been employed to take charge at the Laskalsap (Greenville) School. The records indicate that this school has an enrolment -

Dear Dr. McGill:

I have received your letter of November 22nd, your file 168-35-1, with enclosures regarding the vacancies in certain Indian Day Schools in the Diocese of Caledonia.

It would not be unfair to say that Bishop Rix himself is to some extent responsible for the vacancies in two of the schools in his diocese, inasmuch as he refused to agree to the transfer of Miss Arrowsmith from Lakalsap to Metlakatla, and the appointment of Miss Bird to Lakalsap, succeeding Miss Arrowsmith. Eventually Bishop Rix did agree to nominate Miss Bird for the Metlakatla School but the delay in his doing so resulted in Miss Bird's acceptance of a position in one of the Provincial schools. Miss Arrowsmith resigned and left the Province.

The reasons given by the Bishop for his stand in these cases were that he wished Miss Arrowsmith to remain at Lakalsap, despite the fact that she had requested a transfer, and that Miss Bird was too young a woman to go into an Indian village where there was not another white person. Miss Bird was at that time twenty-nine years of age and had over four years experience at the Mamillilikulla Indian Day School as well as some three years previous experience as a supervisor and teacher at St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton.

The chief objection to the appointment of Mr. Hayhurst to Greenville, apart altogether from his lack of proper qualifications, is that his wife is the teacher at the Indian day school at Kitwanga, two widely separated points. Aside from this, the employment of man and wife at two different centers is likely to prove the subject of criticism.

Dr. H.W. McGill,
Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Dr. H.W. McGill

December 5, 1941.

With regard to the services of Mr. Bryant at Metlakatla, the Department will remember that his work was not satisfactory there. Indeed, it was of such a nature that, considering his age and lack of Normal School training, he could not be retained in a village where even the Indians had asked for his removal.

Inspector Barry has advised that the appointment of teen-age Indian boys as teachers in our schools, when such boys have not completed high school, could not be recommended by him for the following reasons:

1. The teaching of elementary reading, writing, and arithmetic to beginners is one of the most difficult duties of even professional teachers. No hope of success could be expected in the case of young persons lacking even the most elementary training in methods.

2. Young Indians would not command the respect of the children, and it is highly doubtful if such persons should be given the charge of young Indian girls in school. Moral questions are involved not to mention the difficulties in regard to discipline and possible punishment of pupils.

I may say that I am disposed to agree with the Inspector in this respect.

It would probably be as well to mention here that one of the young Indians suggested by Bishop Rix as a possible teacher did not have a satisfactory record at Coqualeetza. Bishop Rix could not be aware of the records of the various Indian children going through our schools and may very easily make bad mistakes in all good faith.

The B.C. Normal School training is for one year only. Those seeking admission to either the Vancouver or Victoria Normal Schools make application in August and therefore the Provincial Department of Education would have no idea what candidates would apply for enrolment next year.
I should like to emphasize that I am not opposed to the appointment of an Indian as a teacher at any of our schools, provided the Indian has the required training and is otherwise qualified for such duties. The employment of unqualified and only partly educated persons in our schools, even if only as a temporary measure, may easily lead to the loss of the services of some qualified person who may subsequently apply for a position, it being perhaps difficult to immediately dispense with the services of the person temporarily in charge of the school.

During the last few days candidates for two vacancies were interviewed. The nomination of Miss L.W. Faithfull for the Hazelton Indian Day School was forwarded to the Department by air mail a few days ago, and the United Church is submitting the name of Mr. E.G. Moyer for the vacancy at Cape Mudge caused through the recent resignation of Mrs. Goodrich.

Inspector Barry has obtained the names and addresses of a number of candidates who had previously applied to the Provincial Inspector of Schools in this city and I am communicating with these persons with a view to having them interview our Inspector should they be interested in Indian school work.

I regret that Bishop Rix has seen fit to criticize our officials. Inspector Barry and Inspector Coleman have done their utmost to secure suitable teachers for the existing vacancies in our schools, but conditions are not normal, and the refusal of Bishop Rix to cooperate in the matter of the transfer and appointment referred to in the second paragraph of this letter was responsible for the loss of two trained teachers to our service this year. Every effort is being made to secure sufficiently qualified persons to take charge of the schools now vacant for the last half of the school year commencing in January, and I have reason to feel that the situation is likely to resolve itself within the next two weeks.

The nomination of a teacher to fill the vacancy at Chehalis has been made by His Excellency Archbishop Duke and it is going forward to the Department tomorrow.
Dr. H.W. McGill

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Mrs. McConnachie who has been teaching at Lakalsap School, Greenville, since September, will definitely not be returning. Re yours of July 3rd, 1947, file 12-11-2, Mr. Uruski was contacted and interviewed at Rosswood, via Terrace, B. C., on a recent patrol to the interior. This man, age 38, is Canadian born (Winnipeg), of Polish descent, married with 3 children. The two oldest boys 11 and 16, are going to Vancouver Island in the fall to relatives. The youngest, a girl of 6 will stay with the parents. The wife appears to be a nice type of person. Uruski informs me he has no academic experience in teaching, but that he taught his own children as the family have lived in isolated places for years. He states that he did two (2) years at the University of Western Ontario at London, Ontario, in a pre-medical and science course. He has his matriculation in Ontario.

He is not an overly-energetic type, but he seems interested in the Indians and is keen to tackle Greenville. His wife offers to take on the dispenser's work. Uruski states he is a non-smoker and non-drinker. In view of the extreme difficulty in getting anyone for this village, the appointment of Uruski as teacher and his wife as dispenser is recommended. Appointment to be as at Prince Rupert and we will make arrangements to take them in. He could go in early and could do some work for a couple of weeks repairing the teacherage, school and sidewalks.

The Department's instructions will be appreciated.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, April 11th, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, enclosing a report showing the work being conducted by Mr. Frederick Job in the teaching of night classes for the young men of the village at Lakasap (Greenville) during the months of January and February, last, and requesting that he be remunerated for this service.

In reply I beg to say that the Department prefers that any remuneration for this service be in the way of an increase in the regular salary of Mr. Job. At the present time he is in receipt of salary at the rate of $105 per teaching month. In view of the services he performs in holding night classes at this school, the Department will increase his salary to $110 per teaching month from the 1st of January, last. This increase in salary is on the understanding that he will continue to conduct these night classes during the period there is a fair average attendance of the young men. This is the full amount we are prepared to allow for the services which he performs at this point. The Department will be pleased to approve of his continuing in the work as teacher at this school for the next school year. We note that you report his services to be satisfactory. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 16th last relative to the Greenville Indian Day School and in reply would state it would not be possible to keep the school open during the months of July and August as suggested as the Indians are all away at the canneries during these months.

September, October, November, December, January and February are generally the best school months during the year. Early in March the Indians leave for Fishery Bay to engage in the oolachan fishing and they do not return to the village until about the middle of April. In May they are constantly on the move putting in their potato gardens etc., and on the 15th June a general exodus takes place to the different canneries at the estuaries of the Skeena and Nass Rivers and they do not return to the villages before the end of August.

The great problem in connection with the school work in this Agency is the fact that the Indians are away from the villages so much throughout the year in pursuit of their living, the children accompany their parents there being no way of looking after them in the villages—thus they lose their attendance at school.

Attempts were made in the past to carry on school work at Fishery Bay during the time the Indians were encamped there and also at one or two of the canneries at the mouth of the river but with little success as the very children who should have attended school were usually engaged helping their parents in the fishing or working in the canneries.

The establishment of a boardingschool for the Agency is a great need and is the only successful way

Sir:

I have to inform you that there has been an overpayment in the salary of J. M. Weaver, First Aid man and dispenser at Lakalsap. As you were informed by official letter of August 18, 1931, Mr. Weaver's salary was to be at the rate of $30 per month. The Department neglected to inform you that, while his duties were to be as above, his salary would be paid as assistant teacher and that it would, therefore, not be necessary for you to include his name on your monthly pay list.

As Mr. Weaver's name was on your pay list each month, cheques were inadvertently issued in his favour from B. C. Vote from October 1, 1931, to the end of April, a period of seven months. He was also paid at the rate of $30 per month from the Appropriation for Indian Education, and cheques for $90 in his favour were issued and sent at the end of the December quarter and at the end of the March quarter. There was, therefore, an overpayment made him of $150, which amount should be refunded by Mr. Weaver or same will be deducted from the salary of his wife and himself at the end of the June quarter. It is presumed you informed Mr. Weaver of the salary that would be allowed in his case, and it is not understood why he accepted duplicate payments.

You should not include Mr. Weaver's name on your monthly pay list in future.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, August 22, 1933.

Sir:

I have your telegram of the 21st instant, recommending the appointment of Miss Pennington as teacher of the Lekslap (Greenville) Indian Day School for the coming school year and Miss G. Parker, graduate nurse, to take charge of dispensary and health matters. In this connection I have to confirm the following night lettergram to you of today's date:

"Appointment Miss Pennington as teacher Greenville School approved. Salary ninety dollars per teaching month, less ten per cent. No funds to pay salary dispenser. Services Miss Parker not required."

With reference to the appointment of a dispenser and matron, I have to say that it has been found necessary, owing to a considerable cut in our Appropriation, to discontinue the services of a dispenser at quite a number of our schools and reserves. Therefore, it will not be possible to approve of the appointment of Miss Parker for this work.

You should inform Miss Pennington of her appointment and arrange with her to take up duties as early as possible in September. Full particulars should be forwarded to the Department regarding her Christian name and the qualifications and experience which she possesses. It is noted that her appointment has been recommended by Mr. Inspector Barry. When writing concerning Miss Pennington's qualifications, etc., you should also state the date on which she began duties.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. E. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert,
B. C.
Ottawa, August 25, 1933.

Sir:

I have your telegram of the 24th instant, advising that, owing to the isolation of the school at Lakeland (Greenville), reconsideration be given to the appointment of Miss G. Parker as dispenser.

In reply I have to confirm the following night lettergram to you of today's date:

"Appointment Miss Parker assistant at Greenville approved STOP Salary Thirty Dollars per teaching month less ten percent."

Miss Parker is to act as dispenser and give attention to health matters on the Reserve. There is no position classified as dispenser or field matron for this Reserve, and Miss Parker's classification will, therefore, be that of assistant teacher. She should prepare, and forward through your office, from time to time, a brief report, stating, in detail, the duties which she carries out.

It will not be necessary for you to include her name on your pay list. Her cheque will be sent at the end of each quarter at the same time as the teacher's salary is being sent. As stated in our telegram, the salary we can allow Miss Parker will be at the rate of $70 per month, less 10% for the ten teaching months in the year.

It is hoped that both Miss Pennington and Miss Parker will meet with every success in their work. I would request that you give them any assistance you can.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. E. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert, B.C.
Ottawa, November 7th, 1933.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of the September quarter return of the Lakalsap Indian Day School and it is noted that the school was only open for ten days during the month of September. Please let me know the exact date on which Miss Pennington and Miss Parker began duties in order that the Department can decide what amount of salary should be allowed them for the period they taught the school during the month of September.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir:

In reply to your communication of November 7th. file 168-35-5, relative to the Greenville Indian Day School, I beg to state that Miss Pennington took up her duties on the 14th September, having left Vancouver on the 8th. She was not able to arrive at the village earlier on account of transportation difficulties and had not been notified in time to avail herself of the monthly gasboat trip up river which carries mail and passengers.

Owing to the fact that it was not Miss Pennington's fault that school did not open at the beginning of the term, I would strongly recommend that she be paid in full.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

During my recent visit to the Greenville Bay school my attention was drawn to the need of a new stove and necessary alterations to the chimney. The old stove is badly cracked and unsafe and should be replaced by a new stove. The chimney at present runs through the side of the building and has been the cause of several small fires. I would recommend that it be taken through the roof and vitrified pipe used above the ceiling as an added protection against fire. The floor of the schoolroom should also be painted. The approximate cost of a new stove and alterations would be as follows:

- 1 Circulator heater stove, $50.00.
- 16 Ft. 8in vitrified pipe @ 65¢ per ft., $10.00.
- 1 Sk. cement, $1.25.
- Lumber and nails, $6.00.
- 2 Galls floor paint @ $6.00, $12.00.
- 1 Paint brush, $.75.
- Labour, $23.00.
- Freight on material from Prince Rupert, $7.00.

Total, $110.00.

A sum of One hundred dollars was placed in the estimates to provide for a new floor for this school. In view however of the greater need of a new stove and the carrying out of the alterations to the chimney, I would recommend that the money, if available, be expended in this way. If sanctioned I shall be glad of an early reply as the work should be taken in hand as early as possible.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Collison,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to forward the enclosed requisition covering various articles and improvements asked for by Mr. and Mrs Hayhurst, teachers of the Greenville Indian Day School, for the teacher's residence. The residence is an addition to the day school.

As Greenville is an out-of-the-way place, and the cost of transportation of household effects to that place expensive, it is advisable to keep a certain amount of furnishings in the house for the use of the teachers, and I would recommend that the enclosed list be provided.

With regard to the beaver board or "gyproc" for lining the dining-room, this will serve to make the room much warmer in the winter and I recommend also that this be provided. Mr. Hayhurst has undertaken to do the work if the material is supplied. The approximate cost, including freight and delivery charges to Greenville would be $75.00, for the entire list of things asked for.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

Requisition for repairs and reshingling material
Roof of teacher's residence & renewal school foundation.

Requisition for domestic science class supplies

Requisition for teacherage supplies

Requisition for classroom supplies, and janitor supplies.

I would state that the sum of $100.00 was placed in this year's estimates for repairing the foundation of the school. Since the estimates were prepared, the teacher has reported that the shingles of the teacher's residence are in bad shape and should be replaced immediately before another winter sets in. The work will be carried out by Indian labor under the supervision of Mr. Hayhurst, assistant teacher.

As the building is very old repairs are needed each year.

I shall be glad to be advised as early as possible in the matter.

Attached hereto is requisition for material for the repairs to the verandah and walk at Lakasap School, Greenville. Attached please find Credit Voucher No. 272 for $149.00 and Voucher No. 265 for $42.17 payable to Gordon and Anderson Ltd., Prince Rupert, B. C.

The Department sanctioned a sum in excess of $300.00 for repairs and equipment for this school, estimate of which cost was based on a report of the teacher who retired in June 1946. When I visited the School in October I found the condition of this teacherage to be such that a great deal more money would be needed than appeared necessary when the funds were requisitioned. The building is not really habitable without extensive repairs and on my return I approached the Bishop for the use of the Mission House if a teacher were secured for Greenville. He agreed that we could have free use of the Mission House which was without equipment or furnishings. An inventory of equipment at the School teacherage was taken and kept on file. In December, the Bishop informed me he had nominated Rev. Arthur Chapman as teacher and that he would arrive in Prince Rupert on January 3rd, 1947 to proceed at once to Greenville. Mr. Chapman had a wife and child coming with him and in view of the extreme need of implementing the furnishings and equipment at this school, I purchased and shipped these with Mr. Chapman's personal effects to Kincolith for transhipment to Greenville. At the last minute Mr. Chapman took ill and was unable to come and we had to have his personal effects returned from the Naas River and shipped east to him. The equipment, furnishings and supplies on the invoices attached have been stored at Kincolith and will be available for a teacher when appointed. It is recommended that the vouchers be approved and paid from votes available.

If a teacher is secured for Greenville, he or she can occupy the Mission House which with equipment there and the new supplies referred to herein, will make a comfortable home.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Your File 168-35-5 WT

I am enclosing Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letter of March 13th and vouchers 272 and 265 referred to therein.

It will be observed that Mr. Anfield used an accountable advance, forwarded to him for labour in connection with repairs to the Lakalsap Indian Day School, reference Mr. Neary's letter of August 23rd last, for the purchase of furnishings for the Anglican Mission House on the Reserve, plus an additional $42.17 for the same purpose. Of the $313.25 requested by Mr. Anfield, in his letter of August 15th, a copy of which was forwarded to you, only a small amount was required for repairs to the teacherage, and it is not seen why the repairs to the school and outbuildings could not have been carried out.

As the matter stands the Lakalsap School building, teacherage and outbuildings are still in need of repairs and an unauthorized expenditure of $191.17 has been made for furnishing the Mission House to which we have no right of occupancy, and which would not be available to us should the church appoint a missionary who would be unsuitable as a teacher.

The vouchers above referred to cover expenditures not authorized by this office or by the Department and until I have your views in the matter I am not prepared to issue a Purchase Order or recommend payment of the accounts. It is considered that Mr. Anfield should be instructed definitely that funds forwarded to him shall not be used for any purpose other than that for which the advance was made without Departmental approval.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C. Vancouver.

Re your 12-11-3 of August 28th, 1947, the 1947-48 Estimates requested a total of $1,750.00 for repairs to Day Schools. It was anticipated at that time that at least part of the new building programme could have been put in hand this year, particularly at Metlakatla, Lakalsap, Hartley Bay and Kitkatla. The items requested were for temporary patching only. In view of the statement of the Department that no new schools can be built this year, it is considered that these repairs be put in hand immediately in order to keep these buildings in operation until such time as a building programme can be undertaken.

It should also be said that these estimates for 1947-48 were prepared at the time when I was supervising two Agencies. I dictated those for the Skeena River Agency to Mr. Findlay who drew them up at my request whilst I was preparing those for Bella Coola in the southern part of the territory. Had I known that no new buildings could be constructed this year, the requests for repairs could have been several times the total submitted. It is noted that $45,500.00 was included for new buildings this year and it is hoped that part of this vote might be transferred to the needed repairs.

Re: Lakelsap Indian Day School

Attached is a request from Mr. Superintendent Anfield for an accountable advance in the sum of $200.00 for draining and clearing land in preparation for the erection of a new school at the above mentioned point. The need for draining is apparently partly due to the small creek referred to in the Agent's letter forming a new channel across the site of the existing building and proposed school. Inspector Davey reports that on his last visit to this reserve he checked on the possibility of locating the school at some other point but the whole area of the village is low lying and there appeared to be no alternative other than to erect the new school adjacent to the old building.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Application is made for an accountable advance in the sum of $200.00 for draining and clearing land on the Lakalsap Indian Reserve, Greenville, Naas River, B. C. It is planned to build a new school in this village next spring and I would like to undertake the digging and draining as well as clearing of this property as soon as possible. There is a creek behind the playing field at Greenville which is draining out under the school and across the lot on which it is proposed to erect the new school. This creek will have to be detoured involving considerable digging. The weather is still open and we could get this done, I believe, before the freeze-up.

The Department's instructions will be appreciated.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.

W. S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B. C., Box 70, Vancouver.

Re: Greenville Indian Day School and Nursing Service.

This village is one of our most isolated units and is often completely cut off from all communication for several months during the winter. We have only a dispensary there with drugs given out by Mr. P. D. Cameron, husband of the teacher, Mrs. Hilda J. Cameron.

As you are aware, we plan on a school construction programme this winter and it is imperative that we have some form of communication. Application is, therefore, made for a radiophone license at this point in the name of the Indian Affairs Branch and authority to rent a phone at a cost of $15.00 per month is requested.

A phone of the right type and size can be obtained through Prince Rupert. The Department's instructions will be appreciated. This should be considered as urgent as the need of communication during the heavy building programme will be evident to all concerned.

Indian Superintendent.

Re: Lakalsap Indian Day School

In view of the increased need for pupilage accommodation at the Lakalsap Indian Day School, we have, since early October, been communicating with Superintendent Anfield, with a view to arranging temporary accommodation in an Indian hall. Our arrangements have now progressed to the point where we have the services of the teacher assured and have for consideration a proposal from Mr. Anfield involving an expenditure of approximately $1,100.00 for improvements to the building, to make it suitable for classroom use and for the provision of accommodation for the teacher.

I might mention at this time that we certainly did not anticipate that an expenditure of this amount would be necessary but are assured by Mr. Anfield that the building cannot be prepared for school use for less and that the materials required will be put to good use when new school accommodation is provided.

Mr. Anfield's letter of November 1st and enclosures dealing with the expenditure necessary are attached hereto and as it would appear that there is little likelihood of our plans for the construction of the new school at this point being proceeded with for some time, I would recommend approval of the expenditure required.

I am writing under separate cover with regard to the appointment of a teacher for this second classroom.

HARRY JACOBSON

North Bay, Kincolith and Tahltan
Indian Day Schools.

Included in our Main Estimates for 1949-50 is the sum of $30,000.00 each for the erection of two-room schools and teachers' residences on each of the above reserves, in the Skeena River Agency, near Prince Rupert, British Columbia.

Whereas our day school building program has met with considerable success in the other provinces, we have encountered many difficulties in British Columbia. At Nelson, we advertised for tenders for the erection of a two-room school and attached teachers' residence and the lowest tender for standard construction was $18,612.00. This same school, we are having built in Similkameen for $27,000.00. As you are aware, we finally decided to erect a prefabricated school at Nelson.

At Cape Breton, we advertised for a one-room school with attached teacher's residence complete with electricity, plumbing, etc. We are having two such schools erected in Ontario for about $17,000.00. The one and only tender received for the erection of the Cape Breton School was $20,744.75.

At Fort St. John, we advertised for tenders for the erection of a two-room Indian day school and teachers' residence but received one tender only, in the amount of $47,351.00.

Therefore, due to the scarcity of contractors bidding on our projects and the high prices demanded by them, our officials in British Columbia have come to the decision that prefabricated
schools should be erected on each of the above three reserves. Their decision in this regard has been aided by the satisfaction obtained from the company which erected the two-room school and teachersage at Pemberton House in the New Westminster Agency and the one-room school at Keshlochto in the Skeena River Agency. This company is Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 485, Vancouver, B.C., and I attach both the previous order-in-Council covering the provision of the Pemberton House School and photographs taken by Inspector Harvey of the completed building.

Our officials are perfectly satisfied with these buildings and Mr. Indian Superintendent Ashfield, who knows how to supervise the erection of this type of school from his experience at Keshlochto, makes the following statement:

"I am satisfied that it will wear well, operate economically and that the type of construction is suitable and most adaptable for the type of country in the Skeena Agency. The school has been viewed with considerable approval by the Provincial School Inspector, Mr. J. Hall, at Prince Rupert. It is recommended that two-classroom schools of this type, with teachersages attached, be constructed at Hartley Bay, Greenville and Kincolith, with the least possible delay."

With regard to advertising for tenders, not only have we our previous disappointments as a guide, but Mr. Ashfield makes the following statement:

"I have approached Messrs. Mitchell and Curry, Green and Bridgman, both contracting firms of Prince Rupert and they refuse to bid on the construction of new schools at these three points, giving isolation of location and risk to transportation as the main reasons. These and other contractors in Prince Rupert have so much other work on hand that they are just not interested."

Mr. Indian Commissioner Ainslie concurs in these recommendations and points out that these buildings can be erected at a cost to the Department considerably less than we could get a quotation from a contractor. In this regard he makes the following statement:
"The mill note Mr. Ashfield's reference to the need for employment at these Indian villages. Erection of these schools will provide some of their much-needed employment and in addition will ensure most urgently required classroom accommodation and, as previously pointed out, at a saving of several thousand dollars in each case."

The only other company in British Columbia producing schools of this type is Precision Housing Company, which produces pre-cut schools. These are much more difficult to erect with the type of semi-skilled Indian labour we will have available and are not recommended by our field officials.

Therefore, I have no hesitation in recommending to you for presentation to the Minister, the attached submission to Council covering the purchase of three prefabricated schools from Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 469, Vancouver, B.C., for erection on those three reserves in the Skeena River Agency. We have foremen-carpenters in mind and can employ the Indians who are fairly competent mechanics and carpenters, under white supervision, for the erection of these prefabricated buildings.

Director.

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1949-50 Estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide three two-room school day schools with attached teachers' residences on each of the following reserves: Hartley Bay, Kincolith and Laxaloop, all of which are in the Skeena River Indian Superintendentcy, near Prince Rupert, in the Province of British Columbia.

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Hartley Bay, Kincolith and Laxaloop Indian Reserves;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest ..........."

THAT due to the very isolated situation of these reserves, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tendering if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 487, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake immediately the provision of these prefabricated two-room schools with attached teachers' residences at each of these reserves, on a basis of $7,750.00 each, f.o.b., Vancouver, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, taxes and expenses;

THAT it is considered that the provision of these schools is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above quoted and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

With reference to my letter of November 5th regarding the proposed expenditure of $1100 for improvements to the temporary classroom and teachersage at the Lakalsap School, and Mr. Neary's Signal reply thereto, apparently Mr. Anfield, reference his letter of November 23rd and Skeena River Agency Voucher No. 1035 attached, undertook to have emergency repairs made before the expenditure was authorized.

The Department has on file photographs of this building and I think you will consider after referring to them that some action was necessary to make the building habitable until the new school is ready for occupancy.

I have issued a purchase order covering the Philpott, Evitt & Company account and would recommend payment of the voucher.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Re the attached voucher No. 1035. I am afraid I have over-stepped things in charging this material but we had to send this stuff in, in order to make the present teacherage habitable for the winter. The heat from the stoves in this building goes straight up through the ceilings and out through the roof. The only way to retain the heat was to seal it in with donnaconal.

These items were included on a previous requisition for a proposed second classroom. It is hoped you will sanction this voucher for payment and cover with a purchase order.

F. Earl Anfield
Indian Superintendent
