Sir,

On the 18th of October of last year I wrote to the Department asking for authority to erect a wood shed at the rear of the Lakgalzap Indian Day school and the necessary authority was received on November 4 (letter #II8532-5) to proceed with the work. On account of the lateness of the season, however, it was found impossible to get the building material to Lakgalzap before the cold weather set in, and, in consequence, I was obliged to postpone the erection of the shed until such time as the lumber could be brought up the Nass River. As there will be an opportunity of doing this in September when the lumber for the re-building of the Indian houses is taken up the river, I should be glad to be informed whether the appropriation for this purpose is still available.

I have just been informed by the Archbishop of the diocese that the mission house at Lakgalzap which has been occupied by Miss Hannam, the school teacher, will not be available this winter as the building will be required for the use of a clergyman and his wife to be appointed next month.

There being no other house at Lakgalzap which can be used by the teacher, especially since the recent fire, I would suggest to the Department that the appropriation be slightly increased so that it may be possible to erect a one-roomed addition to the present school building for the teacher to live in. It is most important that this should be done as otherwise there may be difficulty in inducing the school teacher to remain at Lakgalzap during the coming winter. In out of the way places like Lakgalzap...
 
Ottawa, 20th December, 1945.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Attached hereto is requisition for material for the repairs to the verandah and walk at Lakal-sap School, Greenville. There is a thirty-five foot walk at the back of the school which goes off the main road to the dispensary and teacher's residence, and there is a verandah with steps to the main entrance of the schoolroom. All of this more or less collapsed and will require nearly all new planks. I recommend that this be done before school opens. The approximate cost of Indian labor will be $25.00. Railway, steamship and gas boat freight will be approximately $22.00.

Some minor repairs are needed on the toilets and the back wood-shed, hence the reason for the ship-lap and hinges.

I will make it a point if at all possible to be there when the work is carried out.

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

D.M. MacKay,

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver.

Attached please find Credit Voucher No. 272 for $149.00 and Voucher No. 265 for $42.17 payable to Gordon and Anderson Ltd., Prince Rupert, B. C.

The Department sanctioned a sum in excess of $300.00 for repairs and equipment for this school, estimate of which cost was based on a report of the teacher who retired in June 1946. When I visited the School in October I found the condition of this teacherage to be such that a great deal more money would be needed than appeared necessary when the funds were requisitioned. The building is not really habitable without extensive repairs and on my return I approached the Bishop for the use of the Mission House if a teacher were secured for Greenville. He agreed that we could have free use of the Mission House which was without equipment or furnishings. An inventory of equipment at the School teacherage was taken and kept on file. In December, the Bishop informed me he had nominated Rev. Arthur Chapman as teacher and that he would arrive in Prince Rupert on January 3rd, 1947 to proceed at once to Greenville. Mr. Chapman had a wife and child coming with him and in view of the extreme need of implementing the furnishings and equipment at this school, I purchased and shipped these with Mr. Chapman's personal effects to Kincolith for transhipment to Greenville. At the last minute Mr. Chapman took ill and was unable to come and we had to have his personal effects returned from the Naas River and shipped east to him. The equipment, furnishings and supplies on the invoices attached have been stored at Kincolith and will be available for a teacher when appointed. It is recommended that the vouchers be approved and paid from votes available.

If a teacher is secured for Greenville, he or she can occupy the Mission House which with equipment there and the new supplies referred to herein, will make a comfortable home.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I am enclosing Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letter of March 18th and vouchers 272 and 285 referred to therein.

It will be observed that Mr. Anfield used an accountable advance, forwarded to him for labour in connection with repairs to the Lakalsap Indian Day School, reference Mr. Neary's letter of August 23rd last, for the purchase of furnishings for the Anglican Mission House on the reserve, plus an additional £42.17 for the same purpose. Of the £13.25 requested by Mr. Anfield, in his letter of August 18th, a copy of which was forwarded to you, only a small amount was required for repairs to the teacherage, and it is not seen why the repairs to the school and outbuildings could not have been carried out.

As the matter stands the Lakalsap School building, teacherage and outbuildings are still in need of repairs and an unauthorized expenditure of £191.17 has been made for furnishing the Mission House to which we have no right of occupancy, and which would not be available to us should the church appoint a missionary who would be unsuitable as a teacher.

The vouchers above referred to cover expenditures not authorized by this office or by the Department and until I have your views in the matter I am not prepared to issue a Purchase Order or recommend payment of the accounts. It is considered that Mr. Anfield should be instructed definitely that funds forwarded to him shall not be used for any purpose other than that for which the advance was made without Departmental approval.

P. W. MacKay,

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C. Vancouver.

Re your 12-11-3 of August 28th, 1947, the 1947-48 Estimates requested a total of $1,760.00 for repairs to Day Schools. It was anticipated at that time that at least part of the new building programme could have been put in hand this year, particularly at Metlakatla, Lakalsap, Hartley Bay and Kitkatla. The items requested were for temporary patching only. In view of the statement of the Department that no new schools can be built this year, it is considered that these repairs be put in hand immediately in order to keep these buildings in operation until such time as a building programme can be undertaken.

It should also be said that these estimates for 1947-48 were prepared at the time when I was supervising two Agencies. I dictated those for the Skeena River Agency to Mr. Findlay who drew them up at my request whilst I was preparing those for Bella Coola in the southern part of the territory. Had I known that no new buildings could be constructed this year, the requests for repairs could have been several times the total submitted. It is noted that $45,500.00 was included for new buildings this year and it is hoped that part of this vote might be transferred to the needed repairs.

for F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Re: Lakelsap Indian Day School

Attached is a request from Mr. Superintendent Anfield for an accountable advance in the sum of $200.00 for draining and clearing land in preparation for the erection of a new school at the above mentioned point. The need for draining is apparently partly due to the small creek referred to in the Agent's letter forming a new channel across the site of the existing building and proposed school. Inspector Davey reports that on his last visit to this reserve he checked on the possibility of locating the school at some other point but the whole area of the village is low lying and there appeared to be no alternative other than to erect the new school adjacent to the old building.

Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Application is made for an accountable advance in the sum of $200.00 for draining and clearing land on the Lakalsap Indian Reserve, Greenville, Naas River, B.C. It is planned to build a new school in this village next spring and I would like to undertake the digging and draining as well as clearing of this property as soon as possible. There is a creek behind the playing field at Greenville which is draining out under the school and across the lot on which it is proposed to erect the new school. This creek will have to be detoured involving considerable digging. The weather is still open and we could get this done, I believe, before the freeze-up.

The Department's instructions will be appreciated.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Hartley Bay, Kincolith and Lekalasap Indian Day Schools.

Included in our main estimates for 1948-50 is the sum of $30,000.00 each for the erection of two-room schools and teacherages on each of the above reserves, in the Skeena River Agency, near Prince Rupert, British Columbia.

Whereas our day school building program has met with considerable success in the other provinces, we have encountered many difficulties in British Columbia. At Deloslet we advertised for tenders for the erection of a two-room school and attached teachers' residence and the lowest tender for standard construction was $42,612.00. This same school, we are having built in Saskatchewan for $29,000.00. As you are aware, we finally decided to erect a quonset school at Deloslet.

At Cape Mudge, we advertised for a one-room school with attached teacher's residence complete with electricity, plumbing, etc. We are having two such schools erected in Ontario for about $17,000.00. The one and only tender received for the erection of the Cape Mudge School was $29,744.75.

At Fort Babine, we advertised for tenders for the erection of a two-room Indian day school and teacherage but received one tender only, in the amount of $67,391.00.

Therefore, due to the scarcity of contractors bidding on our projects and the high prices tendered by them, our officials in British Columbia have come to the decision that prefabricated
schools should be erected on each of the above three reserves. Their decision in this regard has been aided by the satisfaction obtained from the company which erected the two-room school and teachers'age at Pemberton Meadows in the New Westminster Agency and the one-room school at Metlakatla in the Skeena River Agency. This company is Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, B.C., and I attach both the previous order-in-Council covering the provision of the Pemberton Meadows school and photographs taken by Inspector Davey of the completed building.

Our officials are perfectly satisfied with these buildings and Mr. Indian Superintendent Anfield, who knows how to supervise the erection of this type of school from his experience at Metlakatla, makes the following statement:

"I am satisfied that it will wear well, operate economically and that the type of construction is suitable and most adaptable for the type of country in the Skeena Agency. The school has been viewed with considerable approval by the Provincial School Inspector, Mr. J. Shell, at Prince Rupert. It is recommended that two-classroom schools of this type, with teachers'ages attached, be constructed at Hartley Bay, Greenville and Kincolith, with the least possible delay."

With regard to advertising for tenders, not only have we our previous disappointments as a guide, but Mr. Anfield makes the following statement:

"I have approached Messrs. Mitchell and Currie, Groar and Bridden, both contracting firms of Prince Rupert and they refuse to bid on the construction of new schools at these three points, giving isolation of location and risk re transportation as the main reasons. These and other contractors in Prince Rupert have so much other work on hand that they are just not interested."

Mr. Indian Commissioner Arnell concurs in these recommendations and points out that these buildings can be erected at a cost to the Department considerably less than we could get a quotation from a contractor. In this regard he makes the following statement:
"You will note Mr. Amfield's reference to the need for employment at these Indian villages. Erection of these schools will provide some of that much-needed employment and in addition will ensure most urgently required classroom accommodation and, as previously pointed out, at a saving of several thousand dollars in each case."

The only other company in British Columbia producing schools of this type is Precision Housing Company, which produces pre-cut schools. These are much more difficult to erect with the type of semi-skilled Indian labour we will have available and are not recommended by our field officials.

Therefore, I have no hesitation in recommending to you for presentation to the Minister, the attached submission to Council covering the purchase of three prefabricated schools from Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, B.C., for erection on these three reserves in the Skeena River Agency. We have foremen-carpenters in mind and can employ the Indians who are fairly competent mechanics and carpenters, under white supervision, for the erection of these prefabricated buildings.

Director.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1949-50 Estimates, Indian Affairs branch, Mines and Resources, to provide three two-room Indian day schools with attached teachers' residences on each of the following reserves: Hartley Bay, Kincolith and Laxkasp, all of which are in the Skeena River Indian Superintendentency, near Prince Rupert, in the province of British Columbia;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Hartley Bay, Kincolith and Laxkasp Indian Reserves;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C., 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest ..........."

THAT due to the very isolated situation of these reserves, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures Limited, post office Box 487, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake immediately the provision of three prefabricated two-room schools with attached teachers' residences at each of these reserves, on a basis of $9,750.00 each, f.o.b., Vancouver, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses;

THAT it is considered that the provision of these schools is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.
The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted to enter into a contract with prefabricated structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, British Columbia, for the provision of a two-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residences at each of the Hartley Bay, Similkameen and Lillooet Indian reserves, as outlined above, on a basis of $9,750.00 f.o.b. Vancouver, for each project, or a total of $29,250.00, plus freight, erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the buildings will be available for use by February, 1950.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Further to my army message of November 5th, this will confirm authority for the purchase of a cement mixer at a cost not to exceed $500.00.

I have discussed this matter with the Superintendent of Welfare, and when the account is forwarded here, I would ask that it have the following notation on it:

"Chargeable Jointly to Education Vote and Welfare Vote."

I would suggest that you recommend in a covering letter the percentage which should be chargeable against the Education Vote and against the Welfare Vote. I presume that this cement mixer will be used for welfare purposes after it has served its purpose in the building of these schools.

The draft Submission to Council for the purchase of these three schools from Prefabricated Structures Limited, has been sent to the Minister's office, and we will send an army message immediately the necessary authority is obtained.
No doubt you have been in touch with the company and advised them that we expect to order these three buildings in due course.

Bernard F. Neary,

Sir,

On the 16th of October of last year I wrote to the Department asking for authority to erect a schoolhouse at the rear of the Lekgalzep Indian Day School and the necessary authority was promised on November 1st (letter #17053-1) to proceed with the work. On account of the lateness of the season, however, it was found impossible to get the building material to Lekgalzep before the cold weather set in, and, in consequence, I was obliged to postpone erection of the shed until such time as the lumber could be brought up the Nass River. As there will be an opportunity of doing this in September when the lumber for the re-building of the Indian houses is taken up the river, I should be glad to be informed whether the appropriation for this purpose is still available.

I have just been informed by the Archbishop of the diocese that the vicarage house at Lekgalzep which has been occupied by Miss Hammans, the school teacher, will not be available this winter as the building will be required for the use of a clergyman and his wife to be appointed next month.

There being no other house at Lekgalzep which can be used by the teacher, especially since the recent fire, I would suggest to the Department that the appropriation be slightly increased so that it may be possible to erect a one-roomed addition to the present school building for the teacher to live in. It is most important that this should be done as otherwise there may be difficulty in inducing the school teacher to remain at Lekgalzep during the coming winter. In out of the way places like Lekgalzep...
if has always been a problem to find suitable 
houses for the school teachers and field matrons 
to live in. Teachers will not live in Indian houses 
and I do not think they should be expected to do 
so. Had it not been that the mission house at Lake- 
glen was unoccupied at the time of Miss Hannah's 
appointment and placed at her disposal she would 
not have accepted the position.

The proposed addition to the school building 
could be made very comfortable for this winter and 
if funds should be available next year another room 
could be added.

This addition would be put up for the sum of 
$200.00 which would include labour and freight of 
lumber and other material to the site.

It would be a distinct advantage to have the 
school teacher living close to the school as she 
could look after the school property and as in this 
particular case, the teacher would be saved a long 
trip every morning through the deep snow during the 
winter months.

Your obedient servant,

w e Colburn
Indian Agent

Ottawa, August 17, 1922.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, with further reference to the building of a wood shed at the rear of the Lakalap Indian Day School, also the erection of a one-roomed addition to the present school building, to provide living quarters for the teacher.

In reply I beg to say, with regard to the wood shed, that the Department will renew the authority for the erection of the same. In this respect, you should carry out the instructions contained in official letter to you of November 4, 1921. In this letter you were also given authority to have a plank walk built, the cost of the material for which you estimated to be approximately $30.00. If this work has not been completed, it may be carried out at the time the wood shed is being erected. It is noted that the Indians promised to perform all the labour, if the material for the building of the wood shed and plank walk was supplied.

Regarding the erection of a one-roomed addition to provide accommodation for the teacher, as the building now used by her will be requisitioned for the use of a clergyman and his wife, it is noted that you estimate the cost of the labour and freight on the lumber for this addition to be approximately $300.00. Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter, No. 18532-6, of date August 17 and in reply to the same of August 7.

With further regard to the erection of the proposed addition to the Lakgalzap Indian Day school for the use of the school teacher, which I am glad the Department has sanctioned, I beg to state that since writing my letter regarding the matter, it has been possible to go thoroughly into the probable cost, which, including all material, labour and transport, the erection of lumber to site will amount to about $1000.00.

A carefully prepared estimate of all material required for the completion of the addition is here-with enclosed.

The need of this addition, which should include two living rooms instead of one as suggested in my previous letter, has become more urgent than ever as the teacher, Miss Hannam, has objected to live in an Indian house—which is not surprising—as it becomes imperative to provide a place of residence as speedily as possible or close the school for the winter, there being no other accommodation in the village.

The matter of providing residential quarters for school teachers has always been a troublesome one, particularly in isolated Indian villages, and the completion of the proposed addition to the Indian Day school should solve the difficulty as far as Lakgalzap is concerned.

Tenders have already been received for the supply of lumber etc., for the re-building of the Indian houses at Lakgalzap. The lumber is to be purchased from the Georgetown saw mill—being the lowest tender—and taken to Lakgalzap on a large scow. It is proposed to send the material required for the teacher's residence at the same time in order to minimize the cost of transportation as much as possible.

As my first estimate was incomplete, I should be glad to receive as early as convenient, by wire, the Department's authority for the expenditure as shown by the enclosed estimate of material for the teacher's residence.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

In forwarding the enclosed Voucher No. 1 with attached account for windows, doors, etc., I beg to transmit also statement of expenditure in connection with the construction and equipping of the teachers' new residence at Langalap. The total cost of materials, labour and transport of such material amounted to $259.36, which is $79.36 more than what was authorized for this purpose, namely $180.00. This can be accounted for by the fact that it was found necessary, soon after the building was commenced, to add another small room for a dispensary, as Miss Hamann also holds the position of Field Matron at Langalap and it was therefore necessary to provide a place where medicines and other medical supplies in connection with her Field Matron duties could be kept. This extra room was not provided for in the original estimate.

The expenditure of $56.36 on a few articles of furniture and stove was an absolute necessity, as Miss Hamann had no furniture of her own, having used the Mission furniture during the time she occupied the Wesley House. The teacher's residence, being now partly furnished, will save considerable expense to future teachers and matrons who may come after Miss Hamann.

The additional expense of an extra room for the purpose of a dispensary and the purchase of a few pieces of furniture, required to make the place habitable for the teacher, has brought the entire cost to $311.36. The most careful economy was exercised in the purchase of everything used in the construction of the building, which is well put together and should withstand the extremely cold weather at Langalap during the long winter months.

I regret it was necessary to spend more than the authorized appropriation but feel sure the Department will realize the unforeseen difficulties and expenses connected with such an undertaking in an out-of-the-way place like Langalap, and authorize the payment of the extra cost as shown in the enclosed statement. I have the honor to be, Sir,

Sir,

I have the honor to inform you that the school teacher's residence at Greenville on Skeena River, will need a new chimney before next winter. When the building was constructed last year, terracotta or drainpipes were used instead of bricks, as they were cheaper and easier to handle. After one winter's use, it has been found that the pipes have not been a success owing to extremes of heat and cold, and are now so badly cracked that it is unsafe to use the chimney until alterations are made.

I have been advised that cement chimney blocks will be even better than bricks, as they are not only cheaper, but can be put together without the services of a bricklayer, which would add so much more to the cost of building a brick chimney. I would recommend that the work be done as soon as possible before the winter school term expires.

As the total appropriation provided last year for the erection of the teacher's residence, was just sufficient to include the cost of painting the residence and the construction of a small woodshed, I would recommend that this also be done before the winter.

The teacher's residence and school house, being all under one roof, I am asking for sufficient roof paint to cover school and residence, as otherwise, the work would look half finished.

The enclosed estimate will show the materials required and approximate cost.

Your obedient servant,

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Mrs. McConnachie, teacher at Nalasap school, Greenville, has asked if she may be allowed the articles which are listed on the attached requisition. I would recommend that they be bought. They can be purchased locally from Gordon's Hardware for the prices quoted thereon.

The kitchen range at the teacher's residence is in very poor condition. Mrs. McConnachie is not able to bake in the oven and it smokes. I recommend that a new one be purchased, as listed on the requisition, which is a cast iron and a very suitable range.

Re: Lakalsap Indian Day School

Mrs. Phillips-Cameron (newly remarried), has just returned from a visit to Greenville to look over the teacherage, which as you know is a pretty grim spot. She informs me that the kitchen range is in extremely poor condition and would like a new one sent in with her when she goes in this weekend.

There are two ranges available locally: (1) At Gordon and Anderson - a Beach Standard at $149.50 (open shelf) and (2) at Gordon's Hardware, an "Escort" range, ordinary, at $147.00, (open shelf). Purchase of one of these ranges plus freight is recommended. The present range is a cheap "Daisy", has been in use for many years, and I can speak from personal experience and say that it should be replaced.

The only furniture in this teacherage is a table and an occasional chair, plus two or three kitchen chairs.

I have today been with Mrs. Cameron and inspected the following used furniture which is in very good condition and a very good price:

One Chesterfield and two armchairs, with new covers, price $50.00. These can be purchased from Mr. Dick Woods, 860 Summit Ave., Prince Rupert, B.C.
One bedroom suite, consisting of double bed, with spring filled mattress; dresser and mirror and chiffonier and chair - Price $100.00. These can be purchased from Mr. Jack Scott, 629-5th Ave., West, Prince Rupert, B.C.

If these items can be purchased, it would make a comfortable house for Mr. and Mrs. Cameron for the winter. All items could be moved into the teacherage when the new school is built next year.

If the Department is willing to purchase used furniture, same is recommended, as these articles new would cost three times the offered price. Will you signal me your instructions.

Yours truly,

Prince Rupert, B.C., June 15, 1908.

My dear Mr. Lorenz,

We would most respectfully urge upon the head of the Indian Department that the time is most opportune to strengthen the Day Schools under Church of England auspices in Northern British Columbia, utilizing for this purpose the money set free by the closing of the Metlakatla Industrial School. Massett would be the best place to begin an improved Day School. It is a large Indian village very much isolated. It has a fine new building erected by the Department and the people. When I last inspected this school there were about forty scholars present and all had not returned after the summer. Provided I had the assurance from the Department that a larger grant would be made I would begin at once to seek for a well qualified teacher, a white man (and his wife); lessons could be given in carpentering to the boys, and sewing, etc., to the girls. Rev. W. E. Collison who looks after the medical needs of the people could give instruction in sanitary matters and care of the health. The people would be far better pleased with this than with sending their children so far away, and I believe the results would be very much better.

Yours faithfully,

"F.H. DuVernet",
Bishop of Caledonia.

Sir,

Absence from the mainland at Nassett, Q.C.I. has delayed my answering your letters of Feb 13 and 19, No 67,340-1, and 125,342-1 which awaited my return.

I take these letters as asking for my candid opinion upon what we all feel to be a most difficult problem. Let me say first that I am most anxious to assist the Department in every possible way in carrying out their new policy of improved Day Schools. I have thought the matter over long and carefully and discussed it with some of our missionaries. I am quite willing to sacrifice denominational pride for the best interests of the Indians. Allow me to express my views freely in hope of helping the cause.

1. No one policy will suit all parts of Canada. It is necessary to modify a general policy according to local conditions. The policy of an improved day school as outlined by the Department seems to suggest the Prairies rather than British Columbia.

2. Speaking for the Church of England in Northern British Columbia let me try and explain the local conditions.

We began Christian work among the Coast Indians over fifty years ago. Our 2,300 Christianized Indians have their homes in villages, most of them live in modern houses, dress well etc. In almost every village there is a clergyman and his wife and family. The clergyman is practically a doctor.

Without

Without any remuneration he is constantly tending the sick, gives practical advice, tells them the danger of evil germs, urges them to keep their houses clean, his wife (like Mrs. Collison of Kincolith) is constantly giving the women hints in domestic matters, there is a day school in the village, usually taught by a white woman, a single lady who lives with the missionary and his wife. It would be impossible for a single lady to live elsewhere in the village. The cost of reaching these villages up the rivers is considerable. The freight on food etc. is excessive, and yet the Department only allows $300.00 a year, subject to reduction, to keep up this Day School, pay travelling expenses and teacher's salary. I have inspected the Day Schools at Nettlacatla, Nikkatla, Nassett, Kincolith, Lakkalzep, Aiyansh, Citwangak, Hazelton etc. and found, not as I have found east of the Rockies, three or four children in a school, but from fifteen to forty five. The younger generation of our Indians have all passed through these Day Schools and the result is far beyond what the Department could possibly expect from such inadequate support. I have heard a young Indian man read the lessons in Church in English better than many white men could and yet he had had no other education than that obtained at the village day school. Viewed in the light of relative expenditure I have no hesitation in saying that there has been far greater returns from the Day School than the so-called Industrial School which on the per capita system could not afford to keep first class trades instructors. It is on this ground that I appeal to the Department to use some of the money saved from the closing of our Nettlactle Industrial School and strengthen these Day Schools which under great disadvantages have accomplished so much good.

It seems
It seems invidious for me to name two of these Day Schools and leave the others out. I mentioned Nassett because it is the largest Day School, 50 on the roll, and the place is 80 miles from the mainland, and Aiyansh because a school midway between Aiyansh and Gitlakdamike would answer both villages and give a good number of children but all these Day Schools should be considered and an increased grant made.

Accepting the policy of the improved Day School and applying it to our local conditions here what are the modifications necessary?

From the description given of our villages it will be seen that a nurse is scarcely needed. Some one should have authority to inspect the Indian houses and order a thorough disinfecting once or twice a year.

Except in the case of a school midway between Aiyansh and Gitlakdamike a mid-day meal does not seem necessary. Many of our Indians are adopting our food. They all have kitchen stoves. They know how to cook. They are not in want. It is mistaken policy for the Government to relieve the parents of the duty of providing for their children.

In regard to industrial training, very few of the children attending day school are old enough to profit from a course of industrial training.

The very best thing the Government could do for our Indians is to employ a first class carpenter and boat-builder and have him visit our villages in turn forming classes of young men from 16 up. Most of our Indians are very quick with tools, the Nassett men build fine schooners. A skilled white man could teach them much that would be most useful in a short course. It would not be necessary to visit each village.
village each year.

Let me now mention the one great difficulty in the way of making the Day School meet the need of the ordinary Indian child. Absence from home at certain seasons. If our Indians lived all the year round in their villages there would be no need whatever for Boarding Schools or Industrial Schools except one central undenominational one for a few of the most promising and perfectly sound children, but this is not the case. The canning season from June 15 to Sept. 1st. does not seriously interfere as most of this is vacation time, but in most of our villages there is another season which comes in March or April when the parents go off and take their children. They would gladly leave them behind them if we could in any way house and feed them for a few weeks. I have thought much over this and talked it over with our leading missionaries. They all agree that this is the problem.

Meet this difficulty and the Day School is all that the ordinary child needs, and the parents will not feel the separation as in the case of a distant Boarding School. "My child might as well be dead" said one mother bitterly when she found she could not get her child back for eight years.

In some cases only a few of the people go away at one time. If we had a man and his wife in charge, a tent that would hold a dozen children, with blankets to might meet the need. I think the parents would be willing to provide food for their children during their absence. Our Missionaries are willing to co-operate as they see the importance of keeping the children at school. The difficulty is that an equipment is needed for a short time.

To come to details. Nasset has 50 children on the roll.
If anything in the way of an improved Day School is attempted, this school should stand first. If the Department takes up the proposal to have a joint school midway between Aiyansh and Gitladamiks, giving a midday meal I understand that the Aiyansh people will give 1 and 1/2 acres, and Gitladamiks the same on the boundary. There is a good road winter and summer. Distance from each village about one mile. As the Department has promised new school houses there should be economy in combining buildings, salaries &c.

As to Hazelton we have a splendid teacher there, Miss Seal, who also is a deaconess and visits the native people in their homes. I have heard that the Methodists are pressing for a Boarding School there. The Church of England has in Hazelton and neighbourhood about 600 Indians, the Methodists none in Hazelton but in the vicinity (10 miles north and 10 miles south) about 270, the Salvation Army a few dozen, the Roman Catholics have a village 3 or 4 miles away.

Plainly the only way to have a successful Boarding School is for us all to unite upon an interdenominational school with the privilege of giving religious instruction to our own flock. So far as our Indians in Hazelton are concerned an improved day school on the line indicated would, I think, meet the need. Why should the Government take children away from their parents and clothe and feed them when these parents live in good houses, earn good wages &c.?

As I have already pointed out travelling expenses are high, the cost of living much greater than in the East, it is necessary to offer a man and his wife a good salary to make...
to make it worth their while to go to an out of the way place and live among Indians. I earnestly trust that the Department will recognize the fact that the Day Schools cannot be made efficient on $300.00 a year. Until I know how much the salary is to be I cannot very well secure capable teachers but I shall be looking out for such.

Yours faithfully,

P.M. DuVernet,
Bishop of Caledonia.

I am requested to inform you of the fact of a meeting for the purpose of discussing the question of the Indians of the North-West, and of the action taken after consultation with Mr. Walter Hope, Chief Commissioner, and others.

Mr. Hope, the former Secretary to the Department of Indian Affairs, has returned here, and the Indians have been called into the Reserve since that time.

The question has been discussed by the Chiefs and other representatives in the matter of sending the Indians (women) away from their homes, and the proposal has been made to send them away. As I have stated, the Indians of this area are very few in number, and there is no reason why they should be removed from their homes. The Indians are not a threat to anyone, and they should be allowed to live in peace and quietness.

In conclusion, I would like to express my sympathy with the Indians of this area, and to assure them that they will be treated fairly and justly.

Sincerely yours,

Queen Charlotte Agency,

Dear Mr. Deasy.-I am today in receipt of your letter of Aug. 31st re. the absence of Mr. Sherwood. I very much regret his action. As the salary is small and it is difficult for us to keep teachers even when the Church adds to the Government Grant and pays the salary regularly every quarter. I told Mr. Sherwood there was no reason why he should not during the Summer vacation, earn a little more money, if he was sure to be back in good time for the opening of the Day School, which was usually about the 1st Sept. I am afraid he has misunderstood matters.

Miss Josephine Edenshaw has been the Assistant Teacher, the Indian Department having promised a supplementary grant for her when the numbers warranted a second teacher (at the rate of $300).

Under the circumstances I think that you and Mr. Hogan have acted most wisely in re-opening the School; but I do not think Miss Edenshaw qualified to take the whole school when it grows larger.

Our Church has been at considerable expense in securing Mr. Sherwood, paying his traveling expenses from a distance. In order to retain his services we, at our August meeting of our Executive Committee, promised him an increase in his salary, as no White man, in any way qualified as a Teacher would teach for the Government Grant alone, even though it has been raised to $500 (subject to reductions).

We also discussed the difficulty about a house for him. I felt strongly that we should not be able to hold him unless we did something in this direction. Compare what the Public School Teachers receive.

I sincerely hope that Mr. Sherwood has long before this returned as it will be hard, at a moment's notice, to secure another teacher. I shall await further word with much concern.
I was very sorry to be away when you called. I hope to be able to go to Massett and have a talk with you over the school question; but I cannot for a few weeks yet.

With kind regards &c.,

(Sd.) F. H. DuVernet,
Bishop of Caledonia.
SENT UP FOR TRIAL
ON CHARGE OF THEFT

Joe Howe Must Face Serious Charge in Higher Court—Gallagher Sentenced to Six Months' Imprisonment.

Joe Howe, a half-breed Chinese, was committed for trial in the higher court yesterday afternoon on charge of stealing $25 from an Indian half-breed named Mathew Youmans at Masset on Graham Island, B.C., Canada. According to the statement of Youmans, Howe came into his house while his limbs were still paralyzed the morning of the theft. Youmans said that he had been in the city giving evidence in a big Graham Island case when he returned home to find the result of previous earnings and fees received in his room by his friend Mr. White, who said that Howe had been there and needed help. They allowed him to sleep on the floor until they heard of his intention for a trip to Victoria. They came back to Vancouver to take him to the police station but the north again and last Friday night had taken him back. When Howe suggested that they should go to the police station to get drunk, he told two men from the North refused to go. Howe then went to the police station where he had a small flask of whisky. He had a small glass and drank from it. Youmans said afterwards that he gave Howe another glass. Youmans said that after drinking it he became unconscious and was unable to lift his arms, and while in this condition left with his money.

When the policeman found Youmans the next day he was crying over the loss of his money as he had not been able to get it back. Youmans went to the North. On the description he gave, Howe was placed under arrest. Mr. L. V. W. Innes, who appeared for the accused, reserved his defence for the higher court.

Sir:-I have the honor to enclose herewith the Report of Teacher N. S. Sherwood, of Massett Indian Day School for the Quarter ending 31st Dec. 1910.

In connection with this School permit me to state that changes are contemplated by His Lordship Bishop DuVernet whereby better results are expected.

I would also be pleased to receive information regarding the School Hours in the Day Schools. In the Massett School four hours per day is considered the longest time for the pupils to attend. It would be far more advisable, in my opinion, to open the School at 9:30 a.m. and continue until noon and to have the afternoon session from 1 p.m. to 3 or 3:30 p.m. The construction of a residence, for the Teacher, would induce some person with a knowledge of teaching to come to Massett, and a married man would, possibly, come then, although the salary provided for a good teacher is insufficient. The female teacher of the "Bite children, at the town 2 1/2 miles away, where only about eighteen pupils attend, receives $85 per month, and is not a teacher with a certificate. The cost of living here is high and $60 per month is not sought after, especially when the teacher must provide his own residence. This matter was brought up before and the conclusion has now been arrived at that, if $1,000 could be appropriated for a residence, and the same built on the Reserve, where the teacher might have an acre of land, it would go a long way in inducing a good teacher to come here and reside permanently. I feel sure the Indians would grant the land and the teacher might erect the residence. His Lordship, Bishop DuVernet, Rev. Mr. Hogan and...
all of us who understand the conditions here, realize that it would be impossible to have good results from a Day School, which is closed a portion of the year, without a disciplinarian in charge. The Teacher we have is not of this stamp and he realizes that he cannot manage the school. He is not at all anxious to continue in charge; but it would be difficult to replace him under present conditions and salary.

In the annual report on the schools reference will be made to this question.

I would also recommend that a Woodshed be built at the School and Water Closets, at a cost of $150. There is no place in which to keep the wood dry, during the rainy season.

The average attendance at the school, during this time of the year, is not what it should be. I am endeavoring to induce the parents to send their children to school; but they will not go to any trouble to see that the children attend. I have gone over the Reserve, time and again, and found children staying away without reason. With a Teacher who would investigate into the reasons for non-attendance and one who would take an interest in the work, good results would surely follow. Such a man requires good pay. His Lordship informed me that an attempt would be made to get such a teacher, and, for the good of the Indians, I hope we will get such a person. The boys and girls who attend the school seem eager to learn and, with a change in the school the parents might take a great deal more interest.

Your Obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your communication (No. 122723/1) of the 9th inst., with reference to "the proposed erection of a school building for the Massett Indians at North Island" and asking me "to advise the Department fully as to what has been done."

The erection of the proposed building was one of the matters that had been in the hands of the former Indian Agent, and, when I took office, was transferred to me.

After considering with the local clergyman it was decided to purchase and store the lumber. The only small sawmill on Massett Inlet has been closed down during the summer and only started work again a short time ago, to cut the timber for the wharf on Massett Inlet. In the meantime I have been anxious to meet His Lordship Bishop DuVernet, to discuss school matters generally, and this school in particular. When I called at his residence, during my visits to Prince Rupert, he was absent, visiting his large Diocese. It was only on my last trip to Skidegate that I met His Lordship—a few days ago.

The local clergyman, and the Indians had changed their minds regarding the utility of building a schoolhouse at North Island. As the map of the Queen Charlotte Group will show, North Island is off the extreme end of Graham Island and is deserted for over ten months of the year. The Indians only go there to fish for "Spring Salmon." There is always the possibility of the Indians giving up this kind of fishing, and now, that a Whaling Station has been placed at Virago Sound, nearer their homes, a number of the Indians will seek employment there. The present Teacher of the Massett Day School gives me to understand that he is allowed to spend the
time the Indian children are away from Massett as he thinks fit, and, during this year, he worked on the Yakoun River — even after the children returned, compelling us to engage Miss Edmonshaw to re-open the school and teach for a month, before he returned. He complains that the salary is not sufficient and, considering that he is appointed by the Bishop, I did not take any further action in regard to his absence further than to confer with the local clergyman and the Indian Council and to ask that the school be opened. His Lordship informs me that Mr. Sherwood, the teacher, has been notified that his services will be no longer required, and I agree with him, for the reason that Mr. Sherwood is not conducting the school as he should.

I did not report on the matter of this schoolhouse until now, in order to find out the views of His Lordship and he is of the opinion that some means should be adopted to keep the children at their homes, while the parents are away, fishing, and at the canneries.

I enclose copies of communications recently received by me, on this matter.

When at Skidegate Reserve, Dr. Spencer also felt that some means should be devised to keep the children of the Skidegate Band at their homes. A child had just died, one that had been several years in the Coquileetza Boarding School. Dr. Spencer said that it would be almost impossible to send any children to Coquileetza School, for some time now, on account of the death of this girl—the Indians considering that it is too far away and they have no means of quick communication should the children in the boarding school become ill.

There is another reason adduced by the Indians for not desiring to send their children to Boarding Schools where a large majority of the scholars belong to the tribes living near the place where the school is located. The few from our outlying settlements are not met in a proper spirit by the Indian children of other reserves, and, being in the large
minority, they feel out of place.

The remedy suggested by both His Lordship, by Rev. Dr. Spencer, by the local clergyman and the Indian Councils is that steps should be taken to open Summer Boarding Schools on the Massett and Skidegate Indian Reserves, either placing the scholars in tents or buildings, and keeping them there while the parents are away. In the past the Indians leave about April and did not return until September. During the rest of the year they received four hours schooling each of the five school days of the week. The balance of the 24 hours they would be back in their homes, talking their native language. While away with their parents they learned little or nothing, and forgot a great deal of what had been taught in the Day School. There are no advanced Day School pupils on either Reserve—in my opinion there never will be, under existing conditions. I can point to a large number of men who graduated from the Boarding Schools, and smart business men they are.

I am pleased to state that all parties concerned on the Massett and Skidegate Reserves, clergymen and Indians, desire to make the schools all that could be desired and their opinion is that Summer Boarding Schools would aid materially. They would keep the young from the influences found around canneries; the clergy would have them all the year round; the teachers would be able to enforce discipline; there would be no break in the studies; the children would be at their homes—where some of the Indians remain and the parents would be reached quickly, should any of them become ill. More than that, I am advocating that we induce the Indians to till the soil and am willing to educate the children in that work. They have the best of land for the purpose and, if our Indians are going to advance, or even keep pace with the incoming settlers, they must be kept away from the baneful influences found in the cities and towns and around the canneries. I enclose a clipping which will show you one recent occurrence. Here we
have the Indians under surveillance. Once away a number of them fall and, when they return to the Reserve are a source of trouble.

I must report, after giving the matter a great deal of consideration, that the building of a schoolhouse, at North Island, would be an expense that would result in little good. If they went to North Island during April and May there would be but forty school days in that term, each day of four hours. Some children would attend, others would be out with their parents, fishing and getting firewood.

His Lordship Bishop DuVernet informed me that he did not feel too sure that any great good would be accomplished—that the plan was suggested to him. The local clergyman, and the Indians themselves do not now consider that we would advance the children very much, in this way. The Indians may stop away from North Island at any time and I think you will agree with me, that we should do everything in our power to keep the Indians, men, women and children, where they are always under the care of their clergy, teachers and agents.

I fully realize the importance of educating the Indians, and am doing everything in my power to make our schools what they should be. In this Agency I am proud of the Indians, who have attended the Industrial Schools, and are endeavoring to aid in advancing the young; but I would advise waiting until next year, before taking any further steps in the North Island School matter. I will try to go there with them and see for myself the condition of things; but, whether the Department carries out the proposition or not, permit me to state that the only way to educate the Indians of this Agency is to give them the education in their homes, on their Reserves.

Your Obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

May it please Your Lordship:

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your communication of the 3rd inst., after my return from Prince Rupert and after the conversation with you over school and other matters.

I also thank you for copy of letter sent to the Massett Indian Council.

The schools of this Agency engaged a great deal of my attention, since my appointment and I am pleased to inform you that the local clergyman, Rev. William Hogan takes a deep interest in the Day School at Massett. We have worked together, and with the Indian Council, to aid the children; but the results have not been all that we expected. The teacher, Mr. Sherwood, is not a disciplinarian and, from my consultation with you, I understand that he is to be relieved. It was not my place to complain, considering that you have Mr. Hogan, who has been visiting the school and keeping the children in order. I understand also that when I am on the ground things have progressed better than before or when I am away in other parts of the Agency. I know nothing of the financial affairs of the teachers and the Diocesan Fund. Each time I received cheques, they were given to the parties to whom addressed. While Mr. Sherwood was at work, at the Yakoun River, and after I found that there was no teacher present when the children returned, I consulted with Rev. Mr. Hogan and the Chief Councillor regarding the opening of the Day School and we were unanimously of the opinion that it was necessary to place someone in charge. Mr. Sherwood knew the Indians were home; but he remained at the Yakoun River until
the work there was finished for the year. It was not my place to ask him to return and, when Miss Edenshaw handed me the quarterly report, to the 30th September, I submitted it to the Department of Indian Affairs. Later I received a cheque in favor of Miss Edenshaw and handed it to the young woman.

Mr. Sherwood returned to Nassett on the 1st October and again took charge of the school, on the 3rd October. From the time I arrived on the Reserve, until Mr. Sherwood took charge, on the above date, I did not meet him in the school. He left here on the 4th July, for Prince Rupert, and returned shortly after. He then proceeded with the river clearing party, to Yakoun River, and did not return until the 1st October. The school had been running one month, under Miss Edenshaw, when Mr. Sherwood returned.

I can well understand that the salary is small for a competent teacher—too small to secure and retain a man qualified; but the Indians are not at home during the months of April, May, June, July and August and I agree with you that something should be done in the way of a summer boarding school, where the children might be kept while the parents are away. We know that the children learn little of any use to them in the country camps and towns—in fact the grown Indians would be better off at home. If we could only have them take up gardening, on the beautiful reserve of theirs, how many girls and young men we would save from the temptations they meet with away from home? I am offering to start them in this line and am writing the Department of Indian Affairs on the question of an experimental garden, to teach them how to cultivate the large stretch of good territory included in this reserve, which is now allowed to go to waste. We could teach the children, if they remained at home and give them a means of making a living in the future. Here your clergyman would have an opportunity to supervise them the year round and the Agent could watch over them also. It would wean the fathers and mothers from going away and they would, naturally, fall into the mode of
life which will eventually mean the preservation and increase of
the Band. Your Church, with the assistance of the Department,
has the best body of Indians I have met in my long experience
with the Indians in British Columbia. As a law-abiding and pro-
gressive people there are no Indians on the Pacific Coast to com-
pare with them. I have been among the Indians, from the North to
the Kootenay country, and know whereof I write. There are men in
this band, who were taught in Metlakatla, who are superior to any
other Indians, and they are anxious to have the children learn
and take their places with the Whites. The Day School will not
meet the wants of the Indians—considering that they go away for
so many months in the year, and I hope the Department will second
the endeavor to keep them at their homes and have them taught
to grow out of the language and customs of former days.

Thanking you for your kind wishes and hoping you will have
a Happy and Prosperous New Year,

I have the honor to be,

Your Lordship's obedient servant,

To Alfred Adams, Chief Councillor and the Members of the Masset Council:

Dear Sirs,

I had hoped before this to visit Massett and talk to you face to face about school matters, which is so much better than writing, but I have not yet been able to secure the time to go over and back.

Your communication regarding the establishment of a Boarding School at Massett followed me about and did not reach me until several weeks after the letter was written.

I fully appreciate the difficulty of retaining the children at school during the few weeks in the Spring when the parents are away and have again and again taken up this matter with the Indian Department in Ottawa. The Department is willing to do anything in reason to tide over these few weeks, but the authorities in Ottawa do not think it wise to take the children away from their parents for a long time, and relieve the parents of all responsibility regarding their own children whom they are bound to clothe and feed. They hold strongly that the results from the Boarding Schools have not justified the immense sum of money spent upon them, and their present policy is to do all they can to improve the Day School. They are willing to provide for the housing of the children, for the few weeks the parents are away but not for the whole year. This is my impression gathered from an extensive correspondence. If the Government is willing to build a suitable Boarding School and bear the whole financial cost I shall be glad to do all in my power to help on the work, but we as a Church feel that we are not justified in spending money on such work. We found at Metlakatla that the Government grant per boy or girl was not enough to pay expenses and we were getting more and more into debt and so had to hand the Indus-

His Lordship: We, the Council of Massett, have considered the question of the children of our Band who require an Industrial School education and consider that there are many reasons why there should be a Boarding School in Massett.

We have had eight children here and they are endeavoring to go to a Boarding School. We applied for places for them and were told that there was only room for two or three at Alert Bay. Some parents are talking of sending their children to Chilliwack and as we desire to have the children taught and raised in their own denominational school, we have endeavored to have the parents wait until something can be done for them. Whenever the steamer leaves for Prince Rupert some children are taken to the wharf at Massett, to be sent to Chilliwack, and some of them would have gone had the parents found someone to take care of them. We feel sure that at least twenty-five boys would attend a Boarding School at Massett and would be left there during the absence of their parents. There are about the same number of girls ready for school. The Day School gives but a few hours' education each school day and all who attend have no more than twenty-four hours of schooling every week, and, for months, there is no school at all. The children live at home, going back to their language and ideas, and there is little improvement, as in school where they live under English teachers and are always under the influence of those who keep them from the streets and are always learning them to talk the English language. We find the Boarding School has brought our people to a stage that cannot be attained in a Day School and as we are anxious to have our children advance, both morally and socially, we ask Your Lordship to take steps to have a Boarding School opened. The Massett Band cannot always be at home, in order to keep their children at school. The various occupations require them to leave for the salmon canneries and other places, where influences are not always for their betterment. They go with their parents to the towns, and see things that children would be better if they did not go there.

There would be no necessity for building the North Island school, as we had a boarding school, and we feel sure that a great benefit would result to our people, both in their learning and their conduct in the world, when they have before them always the influence of Christian teaching.

Trusting that Your Lordship will give our petition early consideration,

Your Obedient Servants,

The Massett Council.

I will not repeat the whole conversation; but it all appeared to hinge on Mr. McConkey's appointment and the reasons for closing the school. In former years the school was closed when the Indians left for North Island.

When the Indians were preparing to leave the attendance dwindled to six children. How many of the 23 would attend now, if the school opened I do not know. This can be understood when I state that His Lordship travels over a large area, and it is difficult to reach him, at times. The teacher receives his instructions from the Bishop and is responsible to him. We have our stated instructions, regarding the school; but no control over the teacher. At the present time, the school is closed. On the 11th inst., the teacher considered that it would be useless to keep the school open. The Indians were preparing to go to North Island, to their fishing grounds, and it was impossible to have a large attendance. On certain days, when I visited the school, but six pupils were in attendance. We used every endeavor

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
to make the children attend, threatening to close the school and interviewing those who would call them together; but they would not attend and the school was closed. The teacher left for Prince Rupert, where, he stated, the Bishop would be interviewed by him.

On my return from Skidegate Reserve Rev. Mr. Hogan interviewed me regarding the children on the Reserve and informed me that the school should be re-opened. He stated that 23 children were on the Reserve; but a number of them had not attended school before the closing thereof and if only six could be relied on at the time (we had only that number at the end of April) I felt that to open the school again would be useless. When we had over 70 children in the village, and only six would attend, the number would surely be smaller when we had but 23 children. Further: The teacher was away and I did not know what arrangements he had made with the Bishop. It has always been usual for the school to close, when the Indians go to North Island and they left on the 15th inst.

During His Lordship's visit, the clergyman, teacher and agent met with him. Questions arose which all present did not agree on. The former teacher informed me that he was under the orders of His Lordship and it was not known how the discipline of the school had fallen until I interviewed the Bishop on the question. The control of this school should be in the hands of a local officer, considering our isolation and the fact that His Lordship is away so often, even from Prince Rupert. Last year, the Teacher did not come to Massett until the children had been home a month. It would not interfere with the moral and spiritual education of the children and the present teacher is of the same denomination with the Indians, and always should be. It would avoid complications and would save a great deal of trouble. You have the Agent near the schoolhouse and he could be called on for advice and instruction. Instead of having the Bishop, clergyman, teacher and agent with separate duties, in connection with the school, where one or the other might consider advice an interference, there would be an understanding of the duties and responsibilities. When the Indians returned from the canneries, they brought "flue" and "smoking cough" with them, and a number of the children died. The canneries are not good for the older Indians, let alone the children. They come back sick and unselfish, losing the moral and other training they had in the past. Some of the women do not return at all and others have lost all restraining influence. Associating with the whites, Japanese and Chinese, at the canneries, is not good for the Indians and, if we could keep the children at home, or in a boarding school, would mean everything for them in the future. As we stated in our conversations, it is a very difficult problem to solve.

There is also the question of the half-breeds. We have some here, and what is to be done with these children? Women marry and live with whites. The men leave them, or they die, and the women return to the reserves, bringing up the children as Indians. The marriage law among Indians is also the source of a great deal of immorality, which cannot be checked as the law stands.

I am sorry to state also that some of the educat-
led Indians are the worst offenders, in the way of drinking intoxicants. They associate with the Whites and appear to imagine that they must adopt some of their evil ways. We are now at the point where the influences of the evil disposed whites are being felt by the Indians of this Island. We now have saloons within a few miles of our reserves; there is no police restraint at all. Law and order is not enforced and it is to be deplored that the Indians are obtaining intoxicants. I cannot arrest men and try them too. Mr. Adams is doing his level best to stop it; but he is practically alone. The clergyman, teacher and agent are doing all they can to make the Indian realise that sobriety is essential to well-being; but the liquor habit is one that appeals to the Indian, and the result of the saloon and the easy manner of obtaining liquor is having its effect, not so much on the old and ignorant Indian, as on those who, through moral training and education, should know better. Before this supplementary Grant at the rate of $300 per annum is allowed to lapse I should like to be assured both by you and Mr. McConkey that one teacher alone is able to teach over fifty scholars. If you deem Mr. McConkey quite able to manage alone perhaps the Department would allow this $300 to be added to his salary provided he remained the year round and added some Industrial training, such as farming, gardening, for boys and his wife teaching sewing &c. to the girls.

From our experience of the great financial cost I hesitate to ask the Department to establish at Massett a full Industrial School. There would
have to be practically two boarding schools, one for boys and one for girls, and if there were twenty in each, from our experience at Metlakatla there would have to be three ladies for the girls school, and at least three, including a qualified trades instructor, for the boys. This means an enormous expense. The per capita grant cannot cover the cost unless there are at least 60 or 70 scholars. I am sure even if the Skidegates joined you could not keep the attendance up to this. If there is a death in the school, followed soon by another at once the parents take alarm and it is only by a warrant that you can force the children back.

Therefore I still favour introducing into the Day School something of the Industrial element. Now that Mr. McConkey has his new house and large grounds I think he could well work in something of this sort especially if his wife will help with the girls, and I think the Department would favour this. Of course if Mr. McConkey is going to make this his life work, settling down in Massett as his home he should receive a larger salary than he is now receiving, and the Department might well add the supplementary Grant to what he is now receiving.

As you are on the spot and have studied the conditions I should like to know your views on the matter.

Yours faithfully,

The teacher can see but one way of keeping the Indian children at school, and that is the creation of a boarding school here at which the Massett and Skidegate children would be taught the whole year. He feels satisfied that over sixty children would attend. Rev. Dr. Spencer, of Skidegate, favors the boarding school. Apparently, His Lordship Bishop Dynevor, did not desire to have a boarding school, under the auspices of the Anglican Church. I understand, from the teacher, that His Lordship has no objection to a school, to be conducted by the government, and under the spiritual direction of the clergy of the reserve. Dr. Spencer asserts that the Indians are not favorable to sending their children to schools located so far from their reserves that they cannot reach them, in times of illness.

It is but one hundred miles, to Skidegate and all of the Haidas are on this island, wintering at two reserves, Massett and Skidegate. They work at fishing, and in the canneries, during the summer, and the day schools have been closed, for months, each year, the Indians taking their children with them. A boarding school would keep the children at home and Dr. Spencer has no objection to the Skidegates attending a boarding school for both bands. Mr. McConkey states that he would take the principalship of a boarding school, under government control, and the head teacher, he suggested, might be a member of the denomination of Rev. Dr. Spencer's church. In the day school there is no control of the children, so far as attendance is concerned. When a family goes away, for wood, or for any other purpose, they take the children, and the attendance is never what it should be. There is, apparently, only one way to properly educate the Indian children of this agency, and that is in a boarding school. I find that few, if any, of the day scholars, who have been in the day schools, that can take their places with the women and children raised in the boarding schools. They attend school for four hours, daily-five days a week-and talk Haida the rest of the time, in their homes and among themselves. The Indians who have
advanced, are the pupils of the Boarding and Industrial School, formerly in Metlakatla. These men are eager to have the children advanced and the Teacher here desires to show results for his labours. He will not continue in the Day School, after this term, feeling that the results, occasioned by the nomadic pursuits of the Indians, takes away his brightest and best pupils.

Considering that the Haidas are looked upon, on this Coast, as Indians apart from the large majority-in advancement-I feel sure the Department will take up this question and assist in making the school arrangements for this Agency the best possible. Indians they are; Indians they will remain; unless we take them from their parents and show them the customs and habits of the Whites, they will not be above the old customs and habits insculpted by their forebears.

Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith Duplicate of a Letter received from His Lordship Bishop F.H. DuVernet, with my answer thereto, in reference to the Massett Indian Day School.

The Teacher, Mr. McConkey, has been over to Prince Rupert, and conferred with His Lordship on the matter.

With the Rev. Wm. Hogan, the Missionary here, I have been to Naden Harbour, and looked over the situation. The Indians are still camping there, in tents, and a number of houses, a cannery and a wharf are in course of construction. We interviewed the Superintendent there, and he is now corresponding with the Managers re. the construction of a combined School and Church, a frame building, 50 feet by 26 feet, with two rooms adjoining, for the accommodation of a teacher. We could take the old desks and the other material, now in Massett Day School, for use there and bring it all back, when the Indians return home, in the Fall.

I do not understand what the intentions of Mr. McConkey, the teacher, are. Whether he will go there, or not, or whether he will remain here, when his contract with His Lordship expires, are matters that I am leaving with His Lordship and Mr. McConkey, considering that he was engaged by His Lordship and is directly responsible to him.

With regard to the contents of the letter from His Lordship, I might state that no instructions are given

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
given the Teacher, at any time, from this office. We inspect and report to you, on the School, and carefully avoid interference of any kind in the management.

The question of an Advisory Board and Governmental control are matters that are not within my province and are submitted to you for consideration.

Mr. McConkey has been advising that a Boarding School is the only solution of the problem of educating the Nassett and Skidegate Bands. This matter also is one that required careful consideration, on the part of all concerned, and I informed him that the Department could not consider it, this year, in time to meet the changed order of things consequent on the Indians moving to another place.

I feel that it would be advisable for a Teacher to go over to Naden Harbour; but he cannot be expected to live there and teach until a residence and a school building have been placed. Considering that it is private property, on which the Indians will live, I also advised that the Cannery Company erect the buildings and allow the Department to use them, for school purposes. Thus they appear willing to do and, when all is ready, I would advise that the Teacher be moved there.

Apparently, the reason for His Lordship's suggestion, with regard to an Advisory Board, is our isolation. There are times when matters of importance should be decided in less than a month. We have but a fortnightly mail and a letter takes a month to receive attention and an answer. I have been consulted, very often, by the Missionary here, Rev. W. Hogan; but cannot take any responsibility that might interfere with the arrangements of the Bishop and the Teacher. The Teacher also consults with me, and I give advice that might prove beneficial; but must always refer him to His Lordship for direct orders, on any matter pertaining to the conduct of the school. Mr. McConkey is not pleased with the advancement being made, and the attendance, desiring results that cannot be attained when pupils are moving from place to place. This, unfortunately, we cannot help. I know that the clergyman, Rev. Mr. Hogan, gives him no instructions.
The School has been going on, all Winter, as usual; but the sudden departure of the Indians has thrown out all calculations, and we now know that they will not return for many months.

The Teacher has just moved into his new residence, and a change, to Naden Harbour, will upset his plans also; but we must do what is requisite for the good of the Indians and it appears to me, it will be necessary to have a teacher at Naden Harbour as soon as the arrangements are made for the accommodation of the children and teacher. We must all remember that we are here for their benefit, and, should it bring inconvenience, the good of the Indians must be our first consideration.

I am also of the opinion that the salary of the Teacher is a fair one. He now has a house and grounds, teaches four hours each school day and has two days in each week to himself and after school hours. The Provincial School Teachers pass examinations and are under expense, for rent and otherwise. Of course, where living is high, and we are isolated, the position is not an enviable one; but we all have to accept conditions, as they are, and the school teacher should take the same view of affairs that we do. Living on a Reserve, among the Indians, is a condition that we make when we accept positions, and, although we would all like to better ourselves, still, the question of duty calls for our best efforts.

Your obedient Servant,
