Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 14th Inst. regarding the Massett Day School.

On account of the manner the people of Massett are shifting about the school problem is a very difficult one. As I am some distance away and it is necessary that action should be taken sometimes without much delay I would suggest through you to the Indian Department that there should be an Advisory School Board for Massett consisting of:

1. The Bishop of Caledonia,
2. The Indian Agent of Queen Charlotte Agency, and
3. The Anglican Missionary in charge of the Massett Band.

That the teacher be employed for the whole year to act under the advice of this School Board. This Board to decide whether the teacher should follow the people from Massett to Naden Harbour, North Island &c.

That in the event of the teacher following the people and teaching the children for the full school year, allowing only six weeks holiday, that the Department be requested to raise his salary and pay him $1,000. a year. The number of school children is large and provided by following them he can secure a good average attendance this, while putting the teacher to some inconvenience, seems about the most economical method of dealing with the problem. By having a School Board the Indian Agent, and through him the Government, not only has, as at present, a general
oversight, but a direct voice in deciding when the teacher should move over to the summer school, when he should take his holiday &c.

As the Indian Agent is resident at Massett this could be done in this case. It seems to me that such an advisory School Board under the circumstances would be a happy solution of one difficulty. At present the teacher scarcely knows whose instructions he is to follow.

As the teacher's full time will be given to the school work, and none to Church work it is only fair that the Government should pay his salary.

As I have already said I am prepared to hand the whole matter over to the Government provided that the Church's right to give religious instruction to our children in the Day School or Boarding School is duly safeguarded.

It is becoming increasingly difficult to secure qualified teachers for Indian Day Schools when we cannot offer a salary equal to the Provincial School teacher's salary.

If you have any suggestion to make I shall be glad to confer with you. Our agreement with Mr. McConkey will end May 15th next. I think it would be a mistake to lose him, and yet I feel that unless something such as I have indicated is done he could scarcely be expected to continue.

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

In my letter of May 30th, dealing in particular with the Massett Indian Day School but touching upon the broad question of the relationship between the Indian Department and the Church authorities in so far as Indian Day Schools are concerned I pointed out the gradual change which is taking place which can only have one conclusion.

Since writing another illustration has arisen bearing upon the same general policy of the Department.

Indian School Inspector has reported to the Department that our lady missionary, Miss Jackson, who has taught the Indian Day School at Metlakatla so faithfully for so many years, should be removed. The Department has written to Mr. Perry, Indian Agent at Metlakatla, instructing him to notify me to this effect, which he has done.

For fifteen years our Church has paid Miss Jackson $500 a year. Up to a short time ago the Department allowed only $300 a year. Now the grant is only $400. Nothing being allowed for travelling expenses in securing a teacher from a distance.

In the Department's letter to Mr. Deasy, Indian Agent at Massett, the following sentence occurs: "It is considered that the question of the time when the teacher will leave Massett for Naden Harbour may safely be left to the judgment of yourself and the teacher." This is conclusive proof that the Department recognizes the Indian School Inspector and the Indian Agent as the authorities to remove, direct, and control the Indian Day School teachers. It simply allows the Church authorities with great difficulty and with much cost to secure a teacher, and add sufficient to the Department's grant to make it worth while accepting, with the possibility of the Indian School Inspector reporting against the teacher.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6402, File 828-1, part 1)
It seems to me that there can be only one possible outcome of such a development. I am not protesting against it. I think it a logical conclusion. If the Department will in the case of Indian villages where our Church has full charge of the religious side of the work only make provision that our missionaries shall have the privilege of imparting religious instruction in the schools to our Church children I see no reason why the Department should not have full control of the Indian Day Schools. As I said in my last letter it might not be wise to change too rapidly—for example in an Indian village far away from an Indian Agent where our clergyman who talks the language is the only white man he must in a sense be the chief representative of Civil as well as Religious authority, but in the case where there is a resident Indian Agent who feels that the Department expects him to exercise authority where Department money is being expended there cannot be any reason for a divided authority. I am not complaining of the action of either Mr. Perry, or Mr. Deasy. They have endeavoured to be fair to the Church. But from the Church's standpoint the drift of events has made the dual position untenable. With a sincere desire to promote the best interests of our Indian Day Schools and to co-operate most cordially with the Department I would in the case of both Nassett and Metlakatla where there are resident Indian Agents, relinquish the privilege so kindly hitherto granted me of nominating the teacher for the Day Schools.

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Department of Indian Affairs, OTTAWA.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th Inst. No. 122,723-1 replying to mine of June 28th. with reference to the administration of Day Schools in this Diocese.

I wish to express my warm appreciation of the action of the Department in assuming the full financial responsibility in regard to the teachers of the Indian Day Schools, as indicated in the words:-

"The Department is prepared to pay to properly qualified teachers the salary paid in the various localities by the Provincial Government".

I also wish to heartily thank the Department for the permission granted in the words:-"In cases where the Department has been able to engage the teacher and where he or she would not be competent to impart the religious instruction, opportunity will be given to allow the Missionary to impart such instruction at proper times."

I assure the Department that our missionaries will do their utmost to co-operate with the Department and that our Church will continue to take a deep interest in the educational work amongst the Indians.

In reference to your criticism of my remark about the Department taking full control of the Indian Day Schools, and your reply "The actual control has always remained with the Department", my point was that "full control" implies "full financial responsibility" which the
Department has now graciously acknowledged.

In connection with the gradual evolution from CHURCH schools to STATE schools which has been quietly going on the last ten years may I point out that in several cases yet such as Hazelton, Gitwangak, Gishgegas, Tahltan, CHURCH BUILDINGS are still being used by the State for the Day Schools, only in the last mentioned place is rent allowed.

I have just returned from a visit to Masset. There were 61 children on the school roll, with over fifty present. The new teacher and his wife seemed to be doing good work. Our missionary Rev. Wm. Hogan, an old school teacher, gives religious instruction at certain times in the week. As this is the first school I have visited under the new plan where the Church does not assume any authority over the teacher I wish to say that I think the plan is working well though the Indian agent fears that $850 is scarcely enough to hold the man and his wife. They have, however, a comfortable house.

Again thanking the Department for taking up the matter presented by me and dealing with it so satisfactorily,

I am,

Yours faithfully,

F. H. Du Vernet
Bishop of Calcutta

Dear Sir:

Not having received any information with reference to the temporary appointment of myself and wife as school teacher and assistant at the Indian Day School at the Reserve, other than the telegram received some weeks ago, I am writing you in the endeavor to find out what has been done with reference to the salary, and whether or not my appointment has been made permanent. Enclosed here from the telegram above mentioned, that the salary would only be eight hundred fifty dollars per annum for the both of us, which I consider absolutely inadequate and insufficient. We cannot live on that amount in this country, let alone care anything about buying any of the rate of seventy dollar per month for two of us. There are over sixty children in the school, and the work is very hard for each of us. We have had to furnish the house and our food, clothing and other necessaries, and we all we could get on that salary. The quality is varied and unless we receive more salary, at least one hundred dollars per month for the two of us, while an assistant is required, for my services alone, I will have to hand you my resignation. I would like to have this matter definitely settled before starting on a new quarter, or as soon as possible.

Yours respectfully,

H.M. Clayberg

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of 17th December last with reference to my report on the Massett Indian Day School.

There appears to be a misunderstanding regarding the children. At the time of writing, Mr. and Mrs. Clayberg were teaching over fifty children, in two rooms in the schoolhouse. Mr. Clayberg had the most advanced pupils—Mrs. Clayberg the junior classes. As you are aware, the children, when they first attend the school, talk only in the Haida language. On the return of all of the Massetts to the Reserve, and living in close neighborhood to the school, small children, that Mrs. Clayberg found it impossible to do anything with, were sent to School. Mrs. Clayberg informed me that it was impossible to teach them anything, and, in endeavoring to make them understand, the others, who were progressing, had to be neglected. It also appeared to me that parents were making a kindergarten of the school, sending children there who could not be advanced in any way. It is only during the winter months that we have an opportunity to have so large an attendance at the school. The progress of the children has been remarkable and the reason is that the teachers classify them. If they give time to the individual Indian children, who are too young to learn anything, it is a loss to the older boys and girls.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ont.
I understand the Indian Act, under the Advancement Part, calls for the attendance of children between the ages of six and fifteen years. In the same schoolroom, with the little children who cannot understand what is said to them—boys and girls, in the junior classes, of the ages of nine, ten, eleven and twelve years. Some of them hardly understand a word of English, and the teachers endeavor to bring them forward. I have seen little children asleep, on the seats, who are too young to be away from home and it is very difficult to judge the ages of the smaller boys and girls.

The teachers are very anxious to have a full roll, and I am sure the winter attendance here is larger than any other Indian Day School in the North. The two teachers have only a few hours each day, and five days a week, to teach the whole of them, and we would only ask to be allowed to send the little ones home that nothing can be done with.

Mrs. Clayberg has been teaching, ever since Mr. Clayberg took over the School. Mrs. Clayberg takes the junior classes, in a separate room, and advances them to Mr. Clayberg's room.

We have not used any person for Field Matron Work. Mrs. McConkey did not teach, at any time. Miss Edensaw is married, and away from the reserve.

I do not know whether Mr. and Mrs. Clayberg will remain. It is difficult to obtain teachers, in this locality, at the salary provided. Living is high here and the Indians refuse to work for less than $2.50 and $3.00 per day. Where teachers have other positions, it augments their salaries; but there is no means of making more than the salary here.

Your Obedient Servant,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th ult., with reference to Mr. H. L. Clayberg, Teacher of the Massett Indian Day School, and the "Regulations governing same."

In reply permit me to state that suggestions made by an Indian Agent should not be ascribed to his knowledge, or lack of same.

I have been given to understand, by His Lordship, Bishop DuVernet, that he no longer desired to have any connection with the conduct of the Massett Indian Day School, further than to give spiritual advice to the pupils. Further than that, I have had no instructions regarding the new conditions caused by the change. Mr. Clayberg was engaged as Teacher, and, in order to avoid any friction, I asked him to interview the Missionary here, before his temporary appointment. His Lordship formerly arranged with the Teacher regarding the time the school should be closed, through non-attendance of pupils. The cheques, for Teacher's salary were sent to the Church authorities, by the Teachers, and no vouchers went from this office. It was, and is now, the same, at Skidegate Indian Day School, which is under the Methodist Church.

His Lordship, Bishop DuVernet, informed me that there was no trouble with our school; but something occurred, at Metlakatla, which caused His Lordship to ask that all schools, where the Agent's reside, should be taken over by the Government. Since that time, Mr. Clayberg was appointed and his salary raised. Under the regulations there are certain pre-

Sir:-I have the honour to report that the following has been received, from Mr. H. L. Clayberg, Teacher of the Massett Indian Day School:

"I note by the Department regulations that the two months' summer vacation, allowed teachers of Indian Day schools may be taken at another time during the year, with the consent of the Department, upon the recommendation of the local Agent. I wish therefore to respectfully request you to recommend to the Department that I be given permission to take my two month's Summer holidays during the months of May and June. It is almost certain that there will be only three or four children of school age in the vicinity by the end of the month. There are less than twenty attending school now, and practically all of these are going to leave with their parents for the fishing grounds within the next two weeks, for the spring salmon fishing, which will last at least two months. I believe it will be for the best interests of the school if I take my vacation at the end of April, for there will be no children here anyway, and after the spring salmon run is over, the first of July, there will undoubtedly be enough either at home or at Naden Harbour to start the school again. I have not as yet been definitely informed as to whether or not my salary will be paid during the holidays allowed by the Department regulations. In addition to this I desire to know whether or not it will be paid in the event there are other times during the year, when I am here ready to teach, but there are no children of school age in the vicinity? It is almost impossible to obtain work around here, and I cannot afford to jeopardize at such times. If there should happen to be times when there are no children here, I could not leave to get work elsewhere, for I would have to hold myself in readiness to open the school when some children returned. I am willing to hold myself in readiness to conduct the school two hundred days in the year, as the regulations provide, at an annual salary of $900, but should it become impossible to hold school the two hundred days in a year, on account of the absence of the children at some time or other, and through no fault of mine, I want to know definitely whether or not my salary will be withheld for such time. I cannot find anything definite in regard to this matter in the regulations, and so I must trouble you for the information. I feel satisfied that there will be sufficient children ready to manage and keep the school open for the two hundred days required; but I want a clear understanding of the matter in the beginning, in case it should occur so there will be no question about it at such time. Trusting you will let me know definitely with reference to these matters as soon as possible and will recommend my vacation as requested above.

I Remain &c., (Sd.) H. L. Clayberg."

With regard to the above, I could give Mr. Clayberg no positive information. In the first place, the Indians have not decided where they will go, this year. We have no information regarding the opening of the Cannery at Naden Harbour, where the Indians went last year. Mr. Clayberg is looking for

I have the honor to report that I visited Naden Harbour and Massett on the 5th of June. I had been informed that school would be conducted at Naden Harbour during the summer months. But on visiting the place I found the school closed, the teacher not being able to get the children to attend. The Indians were divided, a number having gone with their families to "North Island", twenty miles from Massett. The others with thirty children were at Naden Harbour. After failing to get the children to school, the teacher decided to take the summer holidays early, hoping to secure an attendance later.

The Indians were making big wages catching Spring salmon; they do not use nets but troll for them. One Indian and his boy, in a small gasoline boat having four or five nets out, has made a "catch" which has given him an average of $57.00 per day. They get four cents a pound for the fish just as they are caught.

The Indians waited on me expressing their wish for a Boarding School for their children on Graham Island. They stated that formerly they were only away from their villages from two to three months in the summer, living home most of the rest of the year. But now with a whaling station, a cannery and a white settlement they were away so much that the children had a poor chance to learn. They also spoke of their desire to have the children taught to cultivate the soil.

I told them I could make no promises, but would report their wish to you, the Department.

If a Boarding School were established where both the Massett
and delegate children could attend, it would accomplish a great deal more good than the two day schools do at present.

From Naden Harbour I visited Massett and saw Mr. Indian Agent Deasy there. There was only one Indian in the village.

The Rev. Mr. Hogan, the missionary, also spoke strongly in favor of a Boarding School for the two Hydah villages. He stated that in his opinion it was the only way that these children could be educated under the present conditions, which take the people so much from home.

I have the honor to remain

Father Hogan, who was often heard to say that the body was not important and that the soul was, was immediately known throughout the islands in the missionary following. His care and zeal during his long service was a large man with a big heart, almost the entire population of Old Masset ministry in the north had come to love him. His commanding stature and New Masset and a very large number of friends, which lasted until his death, dissolved by death.

Mr. Hogan was taken ill about the first of May, suffering with a cold which had developed into pneumonia. Dr. Kerwin of Prince Rupert was summoned and he arrived on the John a week ago, accompanied by a trained nurse. May, the daughter, was also suffering from the same illness. She had been in bed with the steamer and did not reach here until today. Mr. Hogan's condition was pronounced very grave by the physician, both lungs being affected and the heart action very weak. In addition symptoms of Bright's disease were evident. Mr. Hogan had chills spells, but had rallied on Saturday night and Sunday morning he began to feel rapidly and the end came shortly before eleven o'clock.

A few hours before the final summons the dying pastor repeated the full services of the last rites. At 12 o'clock he hesitated and muttered, "Can't some of you help me out with this?" Then he lapsed into unconsciousness. Father Hogan seemed to have had a premonition that his days on earth were drawing to a close. Several weeks ago, while at the cemetery, he had said to Mrs. Long, "I am going west corner and remarked that he wished to be buried there. When the illness came he lost all heart and expressed the belief that his recovery was hopeless.

Mr. Hogan was born at Enniskerry, County Galway, Ireland 62 years ago and was married in 1884. He left Dublin flowers, the tribute of loving memory, Jesus is born in a world where one has worked with such a man for years, he can understand the loss of 'Father Hogan' and believe that those whom he loved will miss him. Father Hogan was a man of great integrity and a friend to all. He was a man of the highest honour, and at the request of his beloved mother, took his place in the ministry. In youth filled with anticipation and hope, anxious and daring with dreams sufficient for a lifetime, he threw away all worldly cares and worries, and worldly honors, to labor for the saving of souls that were blinded by ignorance and superstition. Far away from home and friends he traveled to the shores of the new continent, like the missionary old, laid down his life for the faith that he had in the Supreme Ruler of the Universe. Among the natives of Port Simpson, and with the Haidas of Masset, he baptized, married, and buried the old and young. Leading them along from darkness into light, he showed them the better road of Christian piety and virtue, the respected 'Father Hogan' was always looked upon as their Chief Councillor and advisor. Twenty years among the Indians of the north, he sought no higher honors than to remain with his charges and well he carried out his mission. With his open, impulsive nature ingrained from birth, he led the Indian members of the Anglican church in such a way that they always respected his sound advice. He had a remarkable memory, and was sought both on the platform and in private, to recite the "deeds of our ancestors," Odin dwells in the fisher's hut and catches a bear. In the Hindu legends, Hari dwells with the peasant among peasants. In the Greek legends Apollo lodges with the shepherds and Jove rusticated among the poor Ethiopians. So, in Anglican church services will be held as usual here each Sunday.

The greatest forest revenue ever paid into any provincial treasury in the history of the Dominion during a single year has been received by British Columbia during the year which has just closed. The revenue from forest sources this year amounts to nearly $3,000,000 or approximately $25 for every inhabitant.

"British Columbia is the only province in Canada which is not overcutting her forests," said H. R. Macmillan, provincial chief forester, in discussing the work of his branch during the past year. "I believe that the forest revenue will largely increase from year to year as the markets for our timber develop and the logging operations which are now merely on the fringe of the forests are expanded until our annual cut keeps pace with the normal forest growth.

"The estimates of an even greater revenue in the future are based upon surveys of the timber wealth of the province, which have been continued during the past year by the forest branch. "The forests of this province, if protected from fire, will, I am confident, form the basis of a future industry of such magnitude that the most optimistic cannot grasp its possibilities today, which will assuredly develop under the creation of new markets on the northern prairies and in northern British Columbia.

"Negotiations are now under way which will lead to an increase in revenue from timber royalties and which will preserve to the people of this province that share of the increment in the potential forest wealth which was provided for under the license system of disposing of timber."

They do not take kindly to the Day School, and are always complaining about not having a boarding, or industrial, school.

At the present time, the Indians are out camping, at Naden Harbour and along the shores, on outside reserves, and there are few left in the Village of Massett.

The past Chief Councillor, and the present occupant of the office have done their best to make parents send their children to school. Sir,

In connection with the schools permit me to state that, Although I understand that children with tuberculosis should have every opportunity to advance, still, in the interest of the majority of the Indian children, I do not think it advisable for children suffering with consumption should associate in the school room with the healthy pupils. The line is drawn, in the Boarding school, and the danger of forty or fifty day scholars, sitting in a heated day school, with children suffering from tuberculosis is just as dangerous as it is in the Boarding school. Our Indians are dying off from tuberculosis and the question is to eradicate it. The medical attendant of the band should visit the day school at least fortnightly and report on the condition of the scholars. In the Massett day school we have now an epidemic of influenza and I requested the medical officer to visit the school and report on the question of closing the institution for a time. The whole village seems to be affected and influenza is a dreaded disease here. So far we have had few deaths for this year, due to the care of the medical officer and all concerned. I am also a believer in giving the children single desks to keep them apart while in school. It is plain to us that many have symptoms of tuberculosis and if we must eradicate that disease we must take extreme measures. If we had a place for patients suffering from the disease, it would help in isolating the cases that are in the homes, roaming the streets and endangering the healthy men, women and children.

With further reference to my letter of the 25th September instant, I have the honour to report that the Indian Day School has been closed, all church services and congregations of Indians suspended, and every endeavour is being made to stamp out the disease, which the Medical Officer reports to be Chicken Pox.

I notified the provincial authorities, and quarantined the families of the affected children in their houses, placing a guard to obtain anything required and to see that they did not leave the buildings.

The Provincial Constable takes "night duty" on the reserve, remaining in the Village until all of the people retire.

It was necessary to obtain food and other necessaries, for the infected families. I enclose accounts for the supplies given them when they were instructed to remain in the houses.

Six families have been quarantined. Notices have been put up, on the houses, and throughout the village, and no children under fifteen years of age are allowed to visit the White settlement, three miles away.

The White residents have been instructed to keep off the reserve.

On account of the Field Matron and Nurse having a family of eight children, I considered it advisable to notify her not to visit the infected houses.

The engagement of Teachers, when we have no children at the schools, means an expenditure that can be avoided in this way. I have suggested that some means should be taken to keep the children at home, by providing them with food and lodging. With the Boarding Schools filled up, and no place to send the children, it is the custom of the Indians to take them to the canneries, and have those that are old enough do work in the canneries. The Indians appear to think more of making money than they do of educating their children. They even try to have the children sent home, from the boarding schools, during the Summer, in order to have them employed.

I objected to this procedure, to the Principal of

Ont.

At Okanagan Industrial Institute, where a number of the Massett and Skidegate children are pupils. In fact, I feel that a law should be passed preventing Indian children, under a certain age, from working in canneries. From my knowledge of the way a large number of the Indians conduct themselves at the canneries, and the class of people they have to associate with, it would be far better for the Indians if they never went away from their homes. Young boys and girls, and Indian women generally, see and learn nothing to their advantage. If we could take the children away from the atmosphere of the cannery and the Indian reserve, until they were able to know something of moral training and hygienic laws, it would be possible to make good, independent, self-supporting people of them.

The engaging of day school teachers, during the summer, when we have the schools open but fourteen days in three months, and but a short time in the previous quarter, shows that at least six months of the year are not of much benefit to the children. The Teachers have two months of a vacation, in June and July, one month in each quarter. An inspection of the schools will show that the Indian children advance very little during the remainder of the year. The parents appear to move away, seeking wood, fish, and for other reasons, even during the winter months, and take their children from school on any pretext. The Truant Officer is busy, when the Indians are at their homes; but he receives little assistance from parents. The Indians consider that they are entitled to a Boarding School, and we find that forcing the majority of them is the only way by which we can get them to the Day Schools, even when they are at home. I must say that the Day Schools in this Agency are not a success, under the conditions found here, in more ways than one.

months, is due to circumstances over which we have no control. We send as many children to Boarding School as can be accommodated, and could send many more.

If the Indians lived in large numbers, at any specified place, during the summer, the Teacher might follow them there. They do not. Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 7th instant, with reference to the application of Peter Hill, for the position of Teacher of Nassett Indian Day School, and your instructions regarding same.

In reply permit me to state that Alfred Adams returned from the fishing grounds, on the 26th inst., he informed me, verbally, that he would accept the position.

Prior to that, Henry Menchow called at the office, and was informed that he might have the place of "Second Teachers." He became very indignant and offensive, and considered that he was entitled to the first place, and stated he would not work with, or under Alfred Adams.

Since then, I have heard that he is at the fishing grounds, at Langara Island, circulating a petition, regarding the Indians fishing in the rivers of these islands. Some of the Indians are signing the paper, without reading it. I certainly told the Indians that they cannot fish in the rivers of these islands, with gill nets, for commercial purposes. In fact, fishing with nets, in any of our rivers, or streams, is illegal. Some time ago, a blind Indian

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
of the Massett Band, named Frederick Young, was fined, by the Inspector of Fisheries, and his net and boat confiscated. I desire to conserve the fish of our rivers, for the Indians. One "gill net" will stretch across any of our rivers, which are, really, what one would call "streams." I enclose a copy of the "Fishing Regulations," and endeavoured to keep the Indians out of trouble, and have fish, for Winter food.

Mr. Edenshaw, with his gasoline launch, towed a scow, belonging to the Wallace Fisheries, to Port Clements, a few days ago. Some Indians were there, catching and smoking fish, for Winter use. An attempt was made to have the Indians sell the fish, "sockeye salmon," caught in the Yakoun river, to the White man in charge of the scow. I informed several Indians that the fish caught in the river, I understand with "gill nets," could not be sold to be shipped to a cannery.

It was after Mr. Henry Edenshaw returned from Port Clements, in company with Chief Councillor William Matthews, and found that Alfred Adams had been appointed Teacher, that he went to Langara Island fishing grounds and asked Indians to sign a petition, which, I am informed, calls in question my work.

The Indians depend on the salmon, from these streams, for their food supply. If they catch, and sell, the fish to canneries, the streams will soon be "fished out." I have not troubled the Indians regarding their food supply, or made inquiries regarding the way they catch fish, in the streams. I tell them not to sell salmon caught in the rivers of this island, to save the Indians from fines, or imprisonment.

A large number of our Indians can sign their names; but cannot read. I have been informed that Indians signed Henry Edenshaw's paper, without understanding the contents. Edenshaw is a man I have helped, in many ways; but he was not the most deserving or most capable man, for the position of Teacher, and he is now indignant, because his wife is not the Field Matron and Nurse.
and he did not obtain the position of Teacher.

Unfortunately, there is a great deal of "jealousy," among Indians. Edenshaw was not a graduate of Metlakatla Industrial School, like Adams and Hill. An Indian girl was appointed Teacher at Skidegate. Peter Kelly, a Haida, is teaching in Nanaimo. I considered that we had Indians here, capable of teaching in the Day school, and so informed you. I did not recommend any; but sent you three names—Adams, Edenshaw and Hill. You instructed me to appoint "either Alfred Adams, or Henry Edenshaw." I appointed the first mentioned—a good, sober, reliable man, without showing favoritism, in any way. Then informed Henry Edenshaw that he could have the second place, if he wished. He indignantly declined, and called in question the appointment of Alfred Adams. Peter Hill will take the place of Second Teacher, and was not offended, at not receiving the first place.

I am writing you, to explain conditions. Have not seen the paper which Henry Edenshaw is placing before Indians, for signature. If there is any complaint therein, that requires investigating, I am willing to give any explanation necessary, and would be pleased to have a copy of same. Considered it advisable to let you know the action of Henry Edenshaw, and William Matthews, who is fishing with him, and who also was at Metlakatla School.

Your Obedient Servant,

Sir,— I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of 14th June ultimo, with reference to the "vacation and salary of Mr. A. J. Clotworthy, Teacher of Massett Indian Day School.

The Massett Indian Day School was closed on the 22nd May last on account of absence of pupils—the children going with their parents to logging camps and other places.

I handed a copy of your letter to Mrs. Clotworthy to be forwarded to Mr. Clotworthy, who is away from the reserve, for a short time.

Mr. Clotworthy did not tender his resignation and I am not aware of his intentions. He has spoken about teaching the White children, at New Massett school, after the Summer vacation; but his family resides in the house of the teacher, on the reserve.

I would recommend that the day school re-open at the Wallace Fisheries, Naden Harbour, at the end of the Summer vacation. A majority of the children will be there for some time, while the parents work in the canneries and fishing for the Company operating there.

In consultation with the Missionary and with the Chief Councillor, we have been formulating a plan to keep the children on Massett Reserve during the Summer months. Rev. Mr. Gillett, the Missionary, has placed his suggestions before His Lordship Bishop DuVernet, for his approval, before taking the matter up with you. It is

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ont.
the custom of the parents to take their children away, during the month of May, and to return about November, in each year. The children receive little education, during the Winter months, and forget a great deal of what they learn, during the Summer. If we could educate them for ten months of each year, how much better it would be for them, and how much more satisfactory for us!

The work our Indians now engage in will mean that the Indians will be away a great deal, even during the Winter months. It is plain that a great number will not send their children to the only available industrial school, at Chilliwack, a long distance from these islands. The parents need the older boys and girls, during the Summer, to produce fish from the sea and to work in canneries. It is almost useless to teach our Indians farming. We have no farms on these islands. Our products are timber and fish. The Indians produce enough vegetables for their own use, in the gardens on reserves, and where they find a little open land, outside.

Teachers, and others, soon lose interest, when a large number of the pupils attend school for a few months, and spend the remainder of their time at Outside camps and towns.

The Teachers' report shows seventy-five children of school age, on the Band roll, and fourteen on the roll of the Coqualeetza Industrial Institute, from the Massett Band alone. This should entitle them to a boarding school. It may not be the proper time to ask for a boarding school; but some means might be devised to keep the children in Massett during the whole school year, and we are working out a proposition on those lines, for consideration. Education is the only hope of the Indian, and we need it more now than ever.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Whites, at Port Clements, and other places, do not want our Indian children in the Provincial pay Schools. Conscription is taking away the Whites. Indians take places in mills and logging camps, assisting in "winning the war," by the production of "aeroplane spruce," of which we have vast quantities on these islands. It is our duty to look into the proper education of the children of these Indians, and I am making suggestions that can be carried out. We have Day School Teachers, coming and going. They teach a few children, during a few months, and want a yearly salary guaranteed, for doing little during a greater part of the year. We cannot expect them to come to these islands, take up this work, and not have enough to live on; but we are looking for the education of the Indian children, in return for the payment of salaries, and the upkeep of the school.

If the Department, and the Bishop, are willing to allow Mr. Gillett and Alfred Adams to take the school, the future work of these two earnest men, who also are looking for results, will be beneficial, far more so than under the present system.

The result was sending Mr. Clotworthy here, and, although he gave satisfaction in his work, he was not content with the arrangements made with him, from the start. Teachers, doctors, constables, and other officials come and go. Even the Missionaries do not stay long on these lonely islands; they look for results from their labours, and soon become dissatisfied with conditions. The Indians remain, and the question is, their welfare, and this depends upon their education.

At the same time, we are of the opinion that we should obtain a fair remuneration for the time we conduct the school. The cost of living has increased. We are families, men, and a White teacher, with only eight pupils, is receiving over ninety dollars per month, at new Massett. With over fifty regular scholars, we received only the sum of $394.80, for our six months services, last year; for the expenses of both of us.

I beg to submit "Quarterly Report" for the term ending December 31st, 1922, on Massett Indian Day School, in this Agency.

The attendance was small until the end of November, when the Indians returned from their camps, and outside employment.

During October and November, Teacher Peter Hill was able to conduct the School. On December 1st, Alfred Adams was called in, and continued teaching during the month.

Two fifty-five pupils have reached Massett, a few days ago, and will be placed at the opening of the School, after the Christmas vacation. The Indians are so eager to have their children at school, that a number of the women remain at home, on the reserve, while the breadwinner is working in logging camp, or at a sawmill, further up the inlet, away from the vicinity of the school.

It appears to me, after visiting the South end of the Province, that the Massett Indians are doing very well, in comparison with other bands.

The Skidegate Teacher reports a large attendance, while the Massetts are doing their level best. We cannot keep them at home, the year round, and it would be a great convenience, to have some means of supporting the children, when the parents are compelled to leave the main reserves, to seek a livelihood. The children cannot be expected to compete with these from the mainland schools, yet it would surprise any visitor to notice the advancement of the "Natives." I have nothing but praise for the teachers of our two day schools, and trust their good work will continue.

Dear Sir:

We as residents of the Massett Reserve would respectfully call your attention to the conditions under which our children are being educated, or rather the excuse of being educated.

For instance - why is it allowed that some of our own people, who have only a very ordinary education, and no training whatever for the position of teacher, are allowed to teach our children, and without any inspection whatever.

Also why is allowed during past years, that any ordinary white man, who has no ability as a teacher, and no training as such, is allowed to teach our children. Is anything good enough for us because we are Indians, even if we are not much expense to the Government. And is it to be allowed forever, that any fad that our agent takes in his head as to the teaching of our children is to be allowed to pass.

We humbly beg to call the attention of your Department to the condition of our people on this Reserve, who instead of advancing in civilization, have been at a standstill for the past ten years. And the cause as we see it is for the want of a good education.

There are at present time about 65 children going to our School here. And about 35 have been sent away to a school at Sardis B.C., which is a big lot of expense to us.

What we earnestly desire you to do, is to do away with the existing teaching conditions here on this Reserve, and let us have properly qualified teachers to educate our children, so that they will have a fighting chance to earn their living, when thrown out on the world. And thus save both the Government added expense as well.

We would earnestly also beseech you to have a duly qualified nurse attached to the School, to take care of our children, and also to teach both them, and their mothers how to have them grow up in a good healthy manner.

We sincerely ask you to give this matter a very thorough investigating, as well as your very best attention, for it has been allowed to now drift along a very long time indeed, and recently this state of things has existed for the benefit of only a few people.

All of which is very respectfully submitted.

We are Yours truly,

The coming year, with the Indians scattered over the islands, will mean that better school facilities will be necessary. Although I was informed that the new Massett Indian Day School would be constructed by October last, no sign of construction is apparent at this date, whether this means that the Department is considering the advisability of erecting a boarding school, or intends to continue teaching the children in a deserted church building, I am not aware. Nevertheless, the largest number of children attending Indian day schools in this province are at Massett. It is true the attendance is falling off from what it was, and it is possible that the Massette will not remain at their main reserve in the future, as in the past. Next year the exodus of the Indians from the main reserve will commence early, and other schools will be required, near the industrial plants, where the Indians will be employed. A falling off of from eighty children to forty shows that families are away from Massett. A few months in a day school will not give us educated Indians.

Every visitor remarks on the advanced condition of the Haida Indians. The parents and children are eager to learn; but there seems to be some barrier to constructing a boarding school where one is most needed. No near-by boarding school will take them; those at Coqualeetza are nearly one thousand miles away from their homes. The parents and the children should be able to see each other occasionally, and the grown boys and girls return to these islands, after an absence of years, in a different environment. If our Indians remained in one place the year round, day schools would be sufficient; but they work, here and there, and take their children amongst whites, Chinese and Japanese, and they learn nothing but evil. Give the Haidas an opportunity and you will have the best Indians in the Dominion. They are a class outside of the ordinary Indians, and their education would mean their salvation. Otherwise they will drift as with many other Indians, and retrograde.

(Sgd.) Thos. Deasy.

Sir,

Can you oblige me by forwarding my cheque for the current quarter to Rev. J. Gillett, Masset, B.C., by return of mail? A power of attorney is enclosed herewith.

My financial obligations are rather pressing, some of which date back to the time in Normal School. The cost of living here is high and a salary of $1050 does not meet the needs of a family. A night school for the older Indians was asked for here and authorized by the Department during Mr. Deasy's term as agent. Owing to the impossibility of securing a teacher at that time nothing was done. The Indians took the matter up with me on my arrival here last winter. After signing up the possibilities I wrote to Indian Agent Gilliom at Prince Rupert. He replied...
at once, that owing to the unforeseen consideration of the scheme would have to be deferred by the Department. He added that I would be at liberty to carry on such a school in my own time.

I conducted night school for three months, three nights a week, two hours a night. The attendance was small, about twelve, but those who attended, attended regularly and took a great interest in the work.

I would be glad to carry on this work under any circumstances, if my salary were sufficient to make ends meet. Under these circumstances I would be glad to have the Department consider the possibility of making some provision for this work.

If it is at all possible to allow something for the past winter's work, it would be very acceptable, as I have so many pressing obligations.

If plans were made beforehand for conducting a night school, the attendance would probably be better, and it could be in session for five or six months.

Dear Sir,

I beg to transmit herewith school reports from the Massett and Tow Hill schools for the quarter ending June 30th.

The school proposition is anything but satisfactory. Mr. Baillie will not be coming back, so that a new teacher will be required for his department. I see no reason why good progress should not be made with qualified teachers using up-to-date methods, the same as in the white public schools.

I have been more or less in touch with the school on the Reserve for the past nine years, and it has made very little real progress. Making allowance for the large number of pupils and the unsatisfactory attendance, I think the greatest fault has been with the teachers. My experience has been that where up-to-date methods are used and the teacher takes a real interest in the pupils, the children are anxious to go to school.

There has been no Inspector here since 1919. I have been wondering if it would be possible to arrange for the Provincial School inspector to visit the Indian Schools. He comes at least once a year, and usually spends a week or more on the Islands. Therefore he would have plenty of time to inspect our schools. According to a conversation I had with the Inspector he would be willing to do it, if arrangements could be made. I feel sure he would be able to give suggestions which would be beneficial, and also be a means of stimulating interest among the parents.

Peter Hill, the Native teacher has done fair work, considering the qualifications he has. I would like to suggest that two qualified white teachers be employed for the coming term. The greatest drawback is the housing situation. If a man and wife, both teachers, could be secured, or two women, the Agency building would be sufficient accommodation.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

In accordance with your request, I found it possible to spend a few hours in your native schools at Skidegate and Massett, after attending to the inspection of my own schools at these points. I beg to give you in a friendly way my finding as follows:

MASSETT:
There is here a large building with two good rooms. While the blackboard space is greater than in the Skidegate schoolroom, it is not so great as a modern school requires. Our ideal today is windows on one side of the room and blackboards on the other three sides.

Most of the children were with their parents at the Tow Hill Clan Cannery. At this point I met with the teacher and children and saw enough of the work to assure me that both Miss Stella Shopland and Miss Dorothy Shopland have proceeded in a modern way to instruct the hundred or more pupils in their charge. It would seem that in these young ladies you have efficient, faithful teachers.

Were this a Provincial school, we would employ three qualified teachers. It is our policy to employ a teacher for less than 40 pupils, two for between 40 and 60 and three for between 60 and 120. With the native children it would seem to me that 25 or 30 to a room would be quite sufficient until the schools had attained a higher standing. I do not see how one could look for really efficient work unless at least one more room were added to this building.

My remarks re attendance, punctuality and library in my report of Skidegate would also apply here.

In closing, I beg to assure you that having the time at my disposal, it was a pleasure to look more intimately than usual into your interesting schools. At the same time, I should like you to regard this as a friendly criticism and not in any way official.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) H. C. Fraser,
Inspector of Schools.

Dear Sir,

The attendance in the Massett school today was One Hundred. The average attendance is always good when the people are in the village. We shall soon be confronted with the problem of the people leaving for Tow Hill, as I understand that the clam cannery there will operate earlier this year than usual.

While there is a school at Tow Hill, it cannot accommodate all the children, and apart from that, the attendance is very irregular on account of the people going back and forth between the clam digs. Also, the cannery life is not conducive to good school attendance, as the gidding is at all hours of the day and night, and the homes are usually in a turmoil.

I have been wondering if the Department would give any assistance towards keeping some of the younger school children in Massett. A good clean house can be secured here which will accommodate twenty-five. It was built two years ago, and is in a good location near the school. It is two and a half stories, well planned, and has plenty of windows. It can be rented for fifteen dollars a month. If the Department could allow twelve dollars a month per child, I think the best of food and management could be met. The people themselves would also be expected to provide at least two dollars a month towards board, and also provide bedding, clothing etc. for the children. The owner of the house, Mrs. Henry White, is a good, clean capable woman,(Indian), and is agreeable to being the housekeeper. Other help, for laundry etc., can be secured, as there are several graduates from Coqualeetza, who are well trained along these lines. The cost of this help, including Mrs. White, can be set out of the $12.00 allowance. The actual cost to the Department would be as follows:

$12.00 per month for 25 children.............$300.00
Rent of house..................................15.00
Fuel and light.................................15.00

$330.00

Would the Department consider trying out the above suggestions as an experiment. It would be an encouragement to the people who are so anxious to have their children educated.

If the Department is prepared to sanction this, I would appreciate a wire, as the cannery is likely to open on February 15th, and the owner of the house would want time to finish off the attic, if the house is to be used.

The Massett Indian Day School has a rather neglected look. There are two fire extinguishers which I asked should be taken out of the corner of a spare room and put one in each of the used schoolrooms. This request was made about four years ago when I first visited the school. I find these extinguishers in exactly the same place now. I have instructed Miss Kowalik that these extinguishers placed one in each of the classrooms, now in use. There is dust in several of the rooms and the floors are quite too clean. I found old sacks in another corner. In general I asked that all the work such about the school be cleaned out and burned at the end of this school term. The floors are washed three times a year by Indians. I understand, I do not believe they do the work properly, and I do not believe they are supervised in it. In fact the whole school requires a thorough cleaning now.

The attendance in September and June is reported by the teacher to be highly irregular, some children coming one day and others another. No proper work could be done under these circumstances. I would recommend that this Massett Indian Day School be not opened in September but on the first Monday in October each year, and that at that time the classrooms be put into use with two teachers, the second teacher taking all children in Grade 1. Later on when the school regains its proper standing and the children are better classified through the Grades the Junior Teacher should have all Grade 1 and Grade 2 at least. I would further recommend that the school be closed at the end of May each year, the two teachers, leaving at the same time.

I have reason to think that the Indians in Massett are rather out of hand at the present time. I understand that some of them are engaged in the production of intoxicants, and that Indians are often drunk on the Reserve. I certainly do not like the idea of the teachers living on the Reserve so many miles from white help, and I would ask the Department to accept my recommendation for the opening and closing of school in future so as to insure that the two teachers are there and not one attempting to live by herself as has been the case in the past. The teacher's house requires repair work inside to keep it in a sanitary state.

Dear Capt. Berry,

I expect you have heard of my resignation from the position of Principal of Massett Indian Day School, and I would like to explain my reasons for doing so.

Miss Gibson and myself were constantly annoyed at night by adult Indians prowling around the house and on one occasion in November a ladder was put against my window and a light flashed in my face as I lay sleeping. This entirely unnerved me, and due to there being no Indian Agent or Indian Policemen in the village there was no one to whom I could appeal for protection. Although this visit was not reported, I was in constant apprehension, and when December came, my nerves were in such an unsettled state, that I decided that my only course was to resign.

I was very reluctant to do this, as I was very interested and attached to my work at the school. I had hoped to be there when you paid your annual visit to the village in May.

I will be glad, and ready at a moment's notice to accept a Primary position (as I am especially qualified for this), in one of your schools, should there be a vacancy.

Will you be so kind as to give me a written recommendation that I could present in the event of hearing of a vacancy locally? I trust that you will consider my work for the past year and a half worthy of this.

I hope for the sake of Miss Gibson, that the Department sends an Indian Agent or an Indian Policeman to Massett this month, and I feel certain that the position of Principal should be held by a much older person.

Yours truly,

Kathleen M. Ker.

I will be glad, and ready at a moment's notice to accept a similar position (as I am especially qualified for this), in one of your schools, should there be a vacancy.

Will you be so kind as to give me a written recommendation that I could present in the event of hearing of a vacancy locally? I trust that you will consider my work for the past year and a half worthy of this.

I hope for the sake of Miss Gibson, that the Department sends an Indian Agent or an Indian Policeman to Massett this month, and I feel certain that the position of Principal should be held by a much older person.

Yours truly,

Gentlemen,

The New Massett Community Club wish to call your attention to the very undesirable conditions under which the white female teachers on the Massett Reserve are obliged to live.

We do not think it right or fair that two women should be obliged to live alone in a community of four hundred and fifty natives, the nearest white person being three miles away.

Although so far the teachers have not been interfered with personally, their house has been broken into on several occasions, and their effects stolen or destroyed, also they have been greatly annoyed by young native hoodlums peering in at their windows and generally making nuisances of themselves.

While not presuming to dictate a policy, we would suggest that suitable quarters should be found in the white town of Massett, with transportation to the Reserve on school days.

Dear Sir,

Last January I received a second letter of welcome when I started my work at Old Man's Indian Day School. At that time I did not feel in a position to answer anything concerning my work as I was so new there.

During the six months at the school I gave a great deal of thought to my work and found that there are two main problems in our work. In the first place, we have splendid equipment and books for the children at school but not sufficient teachers. Last winter we had...
over fifty children of school age and just two teachers. Indian children seem to need more individual instruction than do white children. Next winter we expect over a hundred children and we hope to have three teachers for at least five months.

It would also be a great help for the children to learn the old Indian handicrafts. There are a few old people in the village who do very clever work. My fellow teacher and I would like to suggest that these old people may be paid a small amount to instruct the young people in this valuable work.

Dear Sir:

In your letter 30/6396 of January 26th last addressed to the Department you recommended that the Massett and Skidegate Indian Day Schools be continued in operation until June 30th this year, the established practice being to close these schools on May 31st yearly.

A copy of the above letter was forwarded by you to Inspector Barry for his information but it is not understood why you did not take up this matter with the Department through this office which would have saved both time and unnecessary correspondence.

I am today in receipt of a communication from the Department in which it is stated that there would be no objection to having the above schools remain in operation during the month of June 1942, provided a satisfactory enrolment and average attendance can be assured, and I have been asked to communicate with you in this matter.

In the second paragraph of your letter to the Department you state that the majority of the women and children of the Massett Reserve remained on that Reserve until the end of June 1941 working at the Crab Cannery; you further state that this Cannery will start work in March or April this year and will continue in operation until the Salmon fishing starts, but you do not say when that will be.

The statement that the men of the Skidegate Indian Band are working at the Pacofi Cannery, at the Alliford Bay Air Port, or locally, their families being on the Reserve, does not indicate whether or not the children will be on the Reserve next June.

Before this matter can be finally settled it will be necessary for me to know the total enrolment expected in each of the Massett and Skidegate Indian Day Schools during the month of June 1942 and also the expected average attendance during that month.

Mr. D.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent,
Massett, B.C.
I should be glad to know if you would recommend that both divisions of each of the above schools be continued in operation during June 1942, or if it would be sufficient to operate an un-graded school of one division at each of these schools during that month.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated February 16th, 1942, with regard to the Schools in this Agency remaining open until the end of June of this year.

I am sorry that I sent the above matter direct to the Department, but in conversation with you on my last visit to Vancouver, I understood you to say that certain matters could be taken up with the Department, however, I will in future see that matters of the above nature will pass through your Office.

Referring to the fourth paragraph of your letter, I should have mentioned that the Salmon fishing usually starts about the beginning of July, but last year very few families left the Reserves for North Island, and according to the both Councils they will not be going up there this year, the Crab Cannery at the Massett I.R. will be operating, and several families now in Prince Rupert will be returning to work in the Cannery, and digging clams on the beaches, this operation may go on until the middle of the summer.

At the Skidegate Reserve, they are starting in the Dog fishing (for livers) about the end of May and will continue until the end of July this year as the price of $1.75 per lb is over twice that was paid last year, which was 5¢ per lb. and good money can be made at the above price, the fishing is in the district, so that the families will be on the Reserves.

I have consulted both the Massett and Skidegate teachers with regard to the total enrolment expected during the month of June 1942, and at the Massett school it was expected that an enrolment of 20 in the Senior grade and 35 in the Junior grade, (possibly more) at the Skidegate school, it is expected that there would be an enrolment of about 30 in the Senior grade, and 24 in the Junior grade.

I would like to recommend that both divisions in both schools be continued in operation during the month of June, 1942, and that all teachers be allowed to conduct their respective classes during that period.
In consultation with the teachers of both the Massett and Skidegate schools, all teachers were willing to continue their work during the month of June, 1942, if the above schools be continued in operation.

Dear Sir:

I have the honour to report for your information on the JUNIOR RED CROSS branches at the Massett and Skidegate Indian Day Schools, in the QUEEN CHARLOTTE AGENCY, B.C.

Last year the Massett and Skidegate Indian Day schools were organized as branches of the Junior Red Cross, under the name of the "Haide Juniors".

Meetings are held periodically, and at these, the newsletters are read and discussed and the purposes and responsibilities of the membership stressed.

Health rules are kept as closely as possible; the girls knit face cloths and squares for woolen blankets, they also hem handkerchiefs for the soldiers, the boys meantime are making scrapbooks for a hospital.

The pupils have been are still collecting the following: Rubber, Aluminium, Glass, Silver paper and tinfoil, rags, newspapers & magazines, toothpaste and shaving creme tubes.

Through the aims of the Junior Red cross, we hope not only to help Canada's war effort, but also to raise the tone of the schools, and to arouse in the children a desire to serve the community and their own homes whenever an opportunity arises to do so.

At the Skidegate Reserve, during a Concert given at Christmas time, homemade candy and programmes were sold. Eight dollars were realized, this amount and one dollar from the children's school Junior Red Cross Bank were sent to headquarters to be divided between the Crippled Children Fund and the fund for General War Services.

The children are already planning to hold a programme of school numbers around Easter time, and to sell ice cream at the sports grounds on May 24th., the proceeds from these undertakings will be sent towards the Junior Red Cross Funds.

Yours faithfully,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

My friend, Miss Hannington, has informed me that a teacher is required for the senior room of the Massett Indian Day School at Queen Charlotte Islands, B.C. I wish to apply for the position.

I am thirty years of age. I have taught seven years in rural and graded schools in Saskatchewan. I have a permanent First Class Certificate and am, at present, taking a summer course at the university here to obtain a Superior First Class degree.

I am interested in organized sports and physical training and possess a certificate for the latter.

I am a Protestant - a member of the United Church. I have had considerable experience in Sunday School work and for several years have been in charge of a Canadian Girl in Training group. If my duties should include work along these lines I will be quite pleased to act accordingly.

I have lived near Indians for some years and so I have a first hand knowledge of the type of work that is carried on in Indian Day Schools. I realize the singularity and responsibility of this position and am prepared to co-operate to the greatest of my ability.

I am married and I have a six year old daughter whom I would want to keep with me. If Miss Hannington is chosen as the primary teacher this arrangement is very agreeable to her.

I would appreciate your consideration of my application. If it is of interest to you please wire me at the above address.

Faithfully yours,

(Sgd.) Mrs I. Sutherland.

Dear Sir:

I understand that a teacher is required for the Massett Indian Day School of Queen Charlotte Island; I wish to apply for the position.

I am twenty-two years old and have two years teaching experience. I have a Saskatchewan First Class Certificate which includes Art and Music as well as the basic school subjects.

Besides this, I have certificates for Playground Exercises Training; two Saskatchewan University Courses, Art and Primary Methods, and I am at present attending St. John Ambulance First Aid course.

The Art and Primary Methods courses should be especially suitable for this type of school as it includes handcraft such as clay modelling, weaving, soap carving and such construction, as well as sketching and formal teaching technicalities.

I am a Protestant, and I expect that duties in this school would include some Sunday School teaching; I am perfectly willing to do this.

I realize the responsibility of this position; also that it is unusual. But I am prepared to meet the situation, and am applying to you because I am very sincerely interested in teaching primary classes of this type. I have recently spoken to a Saskatchewan teacher of a "Day" Indian School and I know what to expect.

If my Certificate qualifies me to teach in British Columbia I would appreciate your considering of my application. If so, would you please wire me right away at the above address, or, after July 30th at Wild Rose, Sask.

Thank you very much,

Respectfully yours,

(Miss) Mary V. Hannington.

I enclose herewith copies of two applications received for the vacancies at the Massett Indian Day School for the Junior and Senior Rooms; that of Miss Mary V. Hannington for the Junior Room, and Mrs. I. Sutherland for the Senior Room.

It will be noted that both these teachers are in possession of Saskatchewan first-class certificates and appear to be fully qualified for the positions. Miss Hannington has already been nominated by Bishop Rix and the application of Mrs. Sutherland is now before him and I expect his nomination in the very near future. As teachers are almost impossible to get, I have taken the liberty of assuming that the nomination of Mrs. Sutherland will be forthcoming.

Subject to the approval of Bishop Rix of Mrs. Sutherland, I would recommend the appointment of both these teachers; at a salary of $90.00 per teaching month for Miss Hannington, and a salary of $95.00 per teaching month for Mrs. Sutherland. As you are aware the Massett Indian Day School is vacant, both the senior and junior class rooms, and I have received an application from Miss L. J. QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING JUNE 30th, 1945, ON QUEEN CHARLOTTE AGENCY

Education:

During the quarter I visited the small school at the Hi-Ellen reserve (Tow hill) which was used when the families of the Massett Reserve went clam digging, this last four years they go in and out by Truck, so that the school has not been used, it is in good condition the Forms and tables still being the school, new stove and blackboards would be required if this school is used again.

B.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.
QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING JUNE 30th, 1945, ON QUEEN CHARLOTTE AGENCY

Education:

At the Massett school the attendance dropped down sharply towards the end of the term, this is owing to the families moving off the Reserve to the fishing grounds the canneries. I visited this Reserve ten times during the quarter, visiting the school and teachers residence, where repairs and work was being completed, the senior class pupils who sent in drawings to the Victory Poster Contest at the Stanford University U.S.A. made a very good showing, there being one pupil who received a third prize, and six others who won certificates of merit. The Natives of this Agency appear to be very fond of drawing and music, some very good drawings were on display in both schools during my visits.

B.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.
During the last school year considerable friction developed between Miss L.J. Brunton, teacher of this school, and Mr. Indian Agent Phillips due largely to Miss Brunton's interference in matters entirely outside the scope of her duties as teacher. It is just possible, however, that her real aim was to be helpful. Miss Brunton has had long experience as a teacher and the Inspector's reports on her work at Massett have been favourable. It is doubtful, however, if she enjoys good health, a condition which may not have been helped by the wet, cold climate on the Queen Charlotte Islands. I had a long talk with Miss Brunton following her recent return to Vancouver from Massett and concluded that it would not be in the best interests of the school and our administration there, nor yet her own, for her to return and I would, therefore, recommend that she be not engaged to teach at Massett this coming year. It may be possible to place Miss Brunton in one of the schools much less remote than Massett, and if an opportunity to do so arises she will be advised and the matter referred to the nominating religious denomination.

Mrs. J. Fray, employed as junior teacher at the Massett school, should be re-engaged for the coming school year. Her record is quite satisfactory and she is prepared to return. I should say that an increase of $5.00 per month in her salary is indicated and I would so recommend.

Please let me have an early reply.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

TO THE EMPLOYER:

INCOME TAX DEDUCTIONS AND FAMILY ALLOWANCE PAYMENTS

From salaries and wages paid after 15th July 1945, employers are required to deduct, besides deductions under the Table of Tax Deductions, additional amounts to avoid duplication of benefits for dependent children under The Family Allowances Act and the Income War Tax Act.

The additional amounts to be deducted will be determined by reference to the Percentages shown below, having regard to the information furnished by the employee on form letter TDL-X, a copy of which is attached. Employers must retain the said completed form letters on file for inspection by officers of this Division.

Employers should advise all employees who have made any claims on forms T.D.I for dependent children under 18 years of age that they must complete one of the said form letters if any application has been made for Family Allowance payments in respect of such children. Employers are also requested to make copies of these instructions available to the employees.

Supplies of the form letter TDL-X, and of these instructions, may be obtained from the office of any District Inspector of Income Tax.

Calculation of Additional Deduction

1. From the table below, determine the percentage appropriate to
   (a) the single or married status, and
   (b) the annual earnings over $700, as shown in paragraphs 2 and 3, respectively, of the employee's letter.

2. Apply this percentage to the monthly Family Allowance payment shown in paragraph 1 of the employee's letter. The result is the additional deduction to be made each month if the employee is paid monthly.

3. If your pay period is other than monthly, determine the appropriate deduction to be made each pay day as follows—
   (a) If you pay twice each month, divide the monthly deduction by 2.
   (b) If you pay weekly, deduct 2/9 of the monthly deduction.
   (c) If you pay every two weeks, deduct 4/9 of the monthly deduction.
   (d) If you pay every day, divide the monthly deduction by 26.
