AGEN'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st, 1945.

XX XX XX

Educational:

The Schools of both the Massett and Skidegate Reserves were visited several times each month. At the Skidegate Reserve the Teachers of both the Senior and Junior rooms appear to have things well in hand, and it was noted that the discipline in both rooms are much better than in previous years, a Christmas Concert was held at the Community Hall by the pupils which was very good according to the Council, the parents were particularly pleased with the children. At the Massett school, we only had one teacher, (Mrs Fray) who took both senior and junior rooms morning and afternoon respectively. Mrs Fray was a very good teacher and a good disciplinarian and was very well liked by the pupils, however Mrs Fray was taken out by plane on the 15th of December to Hospital for an operation, her complaint is "Ascites" and the Field Matron has informed me that she will not be returning to teach at Massett, the school of course is closed down.

XX XX XX

B.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, May 15, 1946.

Memorandum:

Mr. HOBY,

Re: Pages 1506 - 1507, Hansard, May 13, 1946.

Mr. H. G. Archibald (Skeena) is reported as having spoken in part as follows:

"I found in the school at Old Massett that the Grade 7 pupils were using Grade 6 books while the Grade 5 pupils were using Grade 4 books. They simply did not have proper textbooks for the children. The Indian Agent has been told of this but no action has been taken. There are no lights in the school and, as Honourable Members know, in that latitude the days are rather short in the winter time. There is no library; there are no reference books and no help has been received from the Agent in connection with these deficiencies. The Indians want to know who inspects the school. Apparently there is no proper inspection."

There are two classrooms in this school and the teachers who were in charge for the academic year 1944-45 resigned at the end of June, 1945. We secured one teacher, but Indian Commissioner MacKay was unable to secure a second teacher. During the period September 1 to December 18, 1945, this teacher conducted the senior room in the morning and the junior room in the afternoon. However, she became ill and had to give up duties on December 19, 1945. Immediate steps were taken to secure a replacement and finally we secured two teachers who began duties on February 1, 1946. The return for the quarter ended March 31, 1946, shows five pupils in Grade 7 and three pupils in Grade 6. These are the first pupils shown in these Grades since we received the return for the quarter ended March 31, 1945.

A requisition was received from the teacher of the

...... Massett
Masset School, through the office of the Indian Agent, last month and the requisition was promptly forwarded to the Government Stationery Office. This requisition requested some books that are prescribed for Grades 7 and 8 in the British Columbia Provincial Schools. These books should have reached the school by this time.

Since our own School Inspector resigned, the Indian schools in British Columbia have been inspected by the provincial inspectors, and on referring to our file I find that the Massett School has been regularly inspected once a year by Inspector Thorsteinson. His last inspection was on May 11, 1945. No doubt, he will visit the school again either this month or next month.

With reference to Kitkatla, Mr. Archibald complained about the condition of the school. We have received a report from the Acting Indian Agent, dated May 4, 1946, regarding this building, and evidently, due to the payment of family allowances, the attendance has increased very materially during the past few months. The Department is writing to him with reference to placing the building in as good a condition as possible, or, if there is any building we could rent, temporarily, he is being requested to report on it.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Queen Charlotte Agency, B.C.
April 5th, 1946.

REPORT FOR MARCH QUARTER

EDUCATIONAL:

The schools of both Massett and Skidegate Reserves were visited several times each month. At the Skidegate school the teacher of the senior room has her class well disciplined, also in this class manual training has been introduced, and the boys have made a bookcase with doors, and shelves for their room, I have recommended that tools be purchased for their use, to encourage them in this work. At the Massett school both the teachers commenced their duties in February, and are doing very well with their classes, they are very active in social work on the reserve, have a teenage canteen and a kindergarten for those under school age under their supervision, the junior teacher (Mrs Conroy) was taken out by plane March 17th with a throat infection to Prince Rupert, but returned to her duties March 25th, both teachers are very well liked by the Indians of the reserve.

B.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.
Q.C.I.
Masset, B.C.

July 4th, 1946.

Sir:

I have the honour to report as follows for the Queen Charlotte Agency, B.C. for the quarter ending June, 1946.

EDUCATIONAL:

The Schools of both the Massett and Skidegate Reserves were visited several times each during the months. At the Skidegate school the teachers of both rooms, have made quite an improvement with their pupils during their terms, and it is regretted that Miss Merritt is being transferred to another school, however we are lucky in having Miss Strong return in her place, she too being a very capable teacher, Miss Mackie the Junior room teacher is staying for another term.

At the Massett school both the Senior and Junior teachers are not returning, both have done very well since they took over in February, however in conversation with Bishop Gibson, who was here on a visit, I was informed that he was sure that he would be able to recommend two teachers for this school for September both the Massett teachers were very active in social work and were very well liked by the Natives.

B.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.

Masset, B.C.
June 18, 1948.

I have today sent you the following wire:

"Miss Manuel, Masset teacher, left sixteenth without authority. Urge Department be advised hold June cheque pending receipt my letter."

This is the climax of a series of events in connection with this girl ever since her arrival at Masset. The situation has become more and more difficult over the months.

1. No effort has ever been made by her to conduct her classes in a proper manner.

2. Her personal conduct has been such to cause me serious concern on various occasions. We have attempted by personal entertaining of these teachers to solve part of their social problems. I have received reports more than once of her being under the influence of liquor.

3. She became enamoured with the local constable prior to his transfer to Queen Charlotte City. On more than one occasion she asked me if she could go there for a visit. She was told that I could not grant her such permission.

4. At the beginning of this week a small freighter was discharging freight at the cannery and when it left on Wednesday, June 16th, at 9:30 in the morning she was on board. I did not learn of this until after its departure. Seemingly the boat was going to Queen Charlotte City from here. Incidentally, the man in question was not there, being on vacation at present. Miss Manuel had the audacity to wire Miss Mackie at Skidegate, a perfect stranger, to meet her.

5. This morning, Miss Shore received a wire from Miss Manuel at Namu consisting of four words, "Going home will wait".

For the first time in three years, this school was in operation from the commencement of the school year. Sir:

A communication has been received from Mr. L. Hamilton Baillie, teacher of the Massett Indian Day School, regarding a number of matters which he states require immediate attention. In this connection I beg to confirm the following night letter to you of yesterday's date:

"Teacher Massett School reports urgent need new stove and heater, to t extra fuel required, repairs needed to drain from toilet at residence and water supply unsatisfactory. Arrange purchase and forwarding stove and heater of suitable types. Obtain supply fuel required and have necessary repairs made to drain and water supply. Keep all expense low as possible."

With reference to the need of a stove and heater, Mr. Baillie states as follows:

"The Department provided a cook stove and a heater when I came here two years ago. The driftwood, which is the only kind available, is very hard on stoves. I have put in several linings, but the stoves are now completely done. It is very doubtful if the top of the cook stove will hold up until a reply can be received from you."

With reference to the fuel requirement, he states as follows:

"The yearly requirement is 20 cords, costing at present $160. We do not waste any, but it is well known that the kind furnished here has no lasting qualities, and the amount used is large. It has worked out as I estimated that 20 cords could be the year's requirement. Seven more cords are, therefore, needed to complete the supply of wood necessary to March 31st, 1927."

W. E. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert,
B. C.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6402, File 828-5, part 1)
Mr. Baillie has suggested that coal be supplied in place of wood; but, owing to the cost in having this delivered, it is considered that as long as wood can be obtained, we would not be prepared to authorize the furnishing of coal.

With reference to the water supply, he states that this has never been properly attended to, the water tank holds only a few days' water, and that, owing to the condition of the cistern, the well cannot be kept in use. In this connection I would refer you to previous correspondence.

With reference to the drain, he states that a flush toilet was provided at the house, a terracotta pipe was put in as a drain fifteen years ago, a part of this drain has crumbled, and the whole thing is therefore out of commission.

As requested in our telegram, the Department would like you to take immediate steps to have the work authorized carried out. The expense should be kept down to the lowest possible point, and properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Nov. 20th 1926

I have your letter of the 17th inst. enclosing account for stoves supplied by Alfred Adams.

Instructions were received at this office from the Department to purchase the stoves for the teacher's residence by tender as is always done with regard to Government purchases, but as you have taken upon yourself to make these purchases without authority, you have placed yourself in rather a peculiar position. However, I will O.K. the account this time, but in future kindly remember that unless directly authorized, you are to make no purchases whatever for the Department.

With regard to the drain pipe, as you have not forwarded the necessary measurements as requested, nothing further can be done until these are received. After making enquiries, I find that the cost of putting in a septic tank would be prohibitive, as it would mean employing a man from here to do the work properly. As the house is so close to the beach and there is good drainage, a septic tank does not appear to be necessary. Instead of a tile pipe as formerly, a wooden stave pipe will be used for the drain as this is easier to put in and will last almost as long. Let me have the correct measurements from the toilet to elbow at edge of bank, thence down the slope to the next elbow, thence to outlet on the beach. I have requested Alfred Adams to go over the ground with you in order that a correct estimate may be made. In the meantime, the part of the drain from the outlet to the break at the brow of the hill should be cleared so that it may be used temporarily until the new pipe has been put in. You may employ someone for a day or two to assist you in opening it up. A plunger has been purchased at the expense
of the Department and is being sent over by this steamer.

As the cost and installation of a new water tank and repairing of the well will cost in the neighborhood of $200.00, I am referring this to the Department for consideration before the expenditure is authorized.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing a voucher covering the cost of putting the wood under the Massett Indian Day School in order to keep it dry, and recommending that a woodshed of sufficient size to store 12 cords of wood be erected, at an approximate cost of $60.

In reply I beg to say, with reference to the woodshed, that the Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding approximately the sum mentioned for the labour and material required in the erection of a woodshed. We note you recommend the size of the woodshed required to be 10'x 24'. If you can arrange to have this building erected for the sum mentioned, you may proceed with the work. You may also arrange to have the floor of the school oiled during the coming Easter holidays. You should purchase the material required for the purpose, and arrange for the labour. We note that you estimate the cost of the oiling of the floors to be about $14.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Sir:

I have the honour to forward herewith the Agent's report for the Massett, Tow Hill and Skidegate Schools, for the month of May. I am also enclosing Mr. Inspector Fraser's letter to the Agent regarding these schools. His remarks on the Massett and Skidegate Schools regarding the number of teachers required expresses the need which the Agent has seen for some time, namely, three qualified teachers for Massett School, and two for Skidegate. Massett this year had over one hundred on the roll, and Skidegate over forty. There will be more in both schools next term.

If the suggestion for three qualified teachers for the Massett school is carried out, it will be necessary to have another room added, such as the Department's original plans called for. I realize that there was not anything provided for in the estimates for 1928-29, to take care of this, so that I suppose the new room will not be added this year. However, the present school could be rearranged so as to make three rooms with very little expense. All that is required is the partition between the large room and the cloak room moved, and two new doors. The enclosed plan of the present school and a sketch of the alteration will show what I mean. If nothing can be done this year, possibly the old Church could be used, as before the new school was built. With a little renovating it would do temporarily, and this would be better than disturbing the present arrangements in the school.

The Skidegate school is quite an old building, I believe originally a church, and a new one will be required in the near future. It is large enough to allow for a temporary partition, so as to accommodate two teachers.

The greatest difficulty is in getting the attendance large enough to require the number of teachers mentioned, during the months of September, May and June. But it could be done from the middle of October to the end of April, with a little more rigid enforcement of Sec. 10 of the Indian Act. The Skidegate attendance has been good for the time the people were in the village. Massett attendance has also been very good, but would have been better if it had not been for the scabies. The people themselves are taking more interest in school affairs and the Agent feels with Mr. Fraser, that if the Indian schools were conducted on the same lines as the White Schools, the results would compare favourably. There would then be no reason why there should not be pupils from these schools taking the Entrance exams every year.

There would be no necessity for hiring the extra teachers for September or after April. I understand that there are plenty of teachers in B.C. who could be obtained at any time. As far as the present teachers are concerned, Miss Dorothy Sheppard will be coming back, but Miss Stella Sheppard hopes to go to University. Miss Macnie will not be returning to Skidegate. Shall I make arrangements to secure a teacher to replace Miss Sheppard. I suppose the United Church will have the privilege of nominating someone for Skidegate.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, June 29, 1928.

Reverend Sir:

I have to refer to that portion of your letter of the 9th instant regarding your suggestion that three qualified teachers be engaged for the Massett Indian Day School and your recommendation that a third classroom be fitted up in the present building. I have to request that you will furnish further information. There are no funds to provide for the erection of another classroom. It is noted from the sketch which you submitted that the present school could be arranged so as to make three rooms with very little expense. Please state the approximate cost of having the partition between the large room and the cloakroom moved and two new doors installed. You should state, also, if any extra desks and blackboard would be required and, if so, give the sizes and the number of each size, and the dimensions - length and width - of the blackboard.

When we have full information as to the cost involved, consideration will be given to authorizing you to have the necessary alterations made for the fitting up of a third classroom. The Department understands that the services of a third teacher would only be required from the first of October to the end of April following in each year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Sir,

In reply to the Departmental letter No. 277-6-5 June 29th, I have the honour to report as follows.

After making careful measurements, it would seem to be the best plan to make both partitions in the Rossetti school, making two rooms of practically equal size. The middle room will have a fire place clock which could serve as corridor for all the rooms. This would lend off the present class-room. This would require a new partition for the clock-room, and one new door to give access to the middle room. The enclosed sketch will show the proposed changes. An estimate for the labour material will be sent shortly. Two hundred and twenty-five dollars. I have consented to go over the plans with you, as this would be more of a reasonable estimate.

Forty-eight feet of bleached pine will be required, including four pieces of first purchase. A Prince Rupert at the time the school is built, this will cost $20.00. A gas stove will also be needed, at approximately $10.00. Including stove pipe. Possibly two to four extra cords of wood will be needed, but this will be determined later. Twenty-five new books will be required, fifteen small size 5s, and ten large ones size 7s.

The extra teacher will be required from November until April, so I take it that the salary will be the same as for the other teachers.

If the Department approves of the above, I would suggest that a wire be sent, so that material can be ordered, and the alterations made before school begins.

Yours obediently,

J. Gillett
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, August 8th, 1928.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th ultimo, relative to the providing of three classrooms in the Massett Indian Day School. The sketch of the present building showing the proposed arrangement in erecting a partition to provide a third classroom and an estimate of the cost was also received. In this connection I have to confirm the following night telegram to you of today's date:

"May arrange to have partition erected Massett School as per sketch enclosed your letter 24th ultimo to provide third classroom. May also purchase blackboard and stove required. Department not prepared authorize second classroom Skidegate as proposed to erect new building next year."

You may, therefore, have the necessary partition erected, obtaining any material required and arranging for the labour. The total cost of the labour and material should not exceed your estimate of approximately $25. You may also purchase and have installed the 6'x8' of blackboard required and a new stove, including the necessary stove pipe. After the work in erecting the partition and the purchase of the blackboard and stove has been completed, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost. The Department will leave the matter of the fitting up of the extra classroom in your hands to make the best arrangements you can at the lowest possible cost.

Relative to the desks required for the extra classroom, I beg to say that you should obtain prices for 25 new desks of the sizes required from the following firms, and purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price:

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing herewith the requisition for School materials for the Massett School.

I would like to have permission to have the floors oiled in all three rooms of this school. The approximate cost will be about $18.00, including the washing of the floors and decks, the floor oil, and the labour in filling.

One of the toilets requires moving, on account of its owing in. The cost of diving and cribbing a hole, and moving the toilet would be about eight dollars. The two toilets also need scrubbing, which will be an additional two dollars.

When this school was built, no provision was made for a flag staff. I think it would be advisable to have one so that the flag can be hoisted daily. Fifteen dollars would cover the cost of poles, halvers, and the erection of same. Would the Department supply a flag for the school?

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent

Ottawa, August 1, 1929.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, relative to the oiling of the floors in the classrooms, the moving of a toilet and the erection of a flag staff at the Massett Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange to have the floors of the three classrooms thoroughly cleaned and given a coat of oil. You may also have the desks washed. I note that you estimate the cost of the material and labour to be about $18. Further, you may arrange for the moving of the toilet to a new site and for the work in digging and cribbing a hole. Both toilets should be thoroughly scrubbed out and placed in a good, sanitary condition. Your estimate of about $10 in this connection is noted. You may also have a flag staff erected, purchase a pole, halyards, guy wire, pulleys, etc. It is noted that you estimate the cost of putting up this pole to be approximately $15.

When the above work has been completed, please forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the material and the labour.

A 9 ft. Union Jack will be forwarded to you for the use of this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. James Gillett,
Indian Agent,
Masset, B. C.
Dear Sir,

In my estimates last year, I included with the flag post etc., a sufficient amount to cover also the cost and installation of a School bell. I had in mind the purchase of the bell in the old Church here. This can be purchased for twenty-five dollars, and with a few minor repairs and the erection of the bell, the approximate cost will be thirty-five dollars. May I have permission to arrange for this to be done?

Your obedient servant,

J. Gillett

Dear Sir,

There are thirty of the Vassett school children with their parents at New Vassett, three miles from the school. They are likely to be there until the end of November, for the clam and crab canning, which is being carried on intermittently.

Since the 7th of this month the cannery manager, on my advice, has been sending these children back and forth to the school here, in the cannery motor bus. Would it be possible for the Department to compensate the Company for the actual expenses incurred? Dear Sir,

The people will be moving out to Tow Hill by the 23rd of February, and clam digging will be starting on the first of March. I take it that it will be the Department's wish to have the school there opened.

The school is a rough building which was put up by the Langara Fishing and Packing Co., in 1926, and is forty-five feet long including a lean-to, and twenty feet wide. In my estimates for 1931-32, I placed an item of $180.00 for shingling this building. The roof at least should be shingled before the school starts, and this will cost $55.00. Are there any funds available this fiscal year, so that the roof may be done at least. Or could I have the whole of the work done, and submit the bills after the first of April. Kindly wire if the Department approves of either of the above arrangements.

I may say that the building is on Hi-Ellen Reserve, but not on the Company's lease. School has been held there each Spring since it was built. Mrs. Ashmore, of the Massett School will be taking charge there if the above is satisfactory to the Department.

Dear Sir,

Referring to Departmental letter No.157-2-5, of February 14th, 1931, I may say the work in connection with Tow Hill school is now completed, and the bills in this matter are enclosed herewith.

I took the liberty of having some extra work done, such as a woodshed, toilets built, and a rearrangement of windows including two new ones, to give better lighting. As the price of shingles had taken a drop since my estimate of cost was made, I found that I could have this extra work done, and still keep within the amount mentioned, ($150.00).

Referring to that part of your letter dealing with the ownership of the school building, I may say that the Langara Fishing and Packing Co. supplied the material for the building and the Indian people put it up gratis. The Langara Fishing and Packing Co. take no claim to the building under the control of the Indian Agent. It practically means that it is the property of the Department, particularly now that repairs have been made out of Departmental funds. The building is used for school only, except for an occasional Church Service.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

Funds are provided in the Main Estimates, Indian Education, for the purchase of the mission house and the lot on which it stands, at Massett, B.C. This is required as a teachers' residence. It is at present in use for the purpose and we are paying a rental of $15 per month. Bishop Rix, of the Diocese of Caledonia, has offered to sell the property for $1,037.50. Mr. Indian Agent Gillett, when recommending the purchase, has forwarded a statement concerning the building and Mr. Orr considers the price very reasonable.

Dear Sir,

The roof of the Indian day school at Massett needs to be stained, and the trimmings on the building need painting. The teachers' residence at Massett also needs staining and painting outside.

The roof of the teachers' residence at Skidegate requires re-shingling and staining.

In my estimates for 1932-33, I placed an item of $275.00 for repairs to the Skidegate teachers' residence and $200.00 for the Massett residence. Through an oversight I failed to estimate for repairs to the Massett school. If the two amounts mentioned above have been granted in full, it will take care of the Massett school as well as the residences, as it is now possible to secure labour at a much lower rate than when my estimates were made.

I should like to have advise regarding this as early as possible, in order to give the work to Indians who would otherwise be on relief. In this case labour would be $2.00 per day.

Ottawa, July 30th, 1937.

Dear Sir,

Indian Commissioner MacKay has forwarded to the Department your letter of the 13th instant, with reference to the necessity for the erection of two toilets at the Massett Indian Day School. It is noted that you estimate the cost of these at $100 and other repairs at $25., or a total of $125.

In view of the fact that you recently authorized repairs to the teachers' residence at the Massett School without receiving authority from the Department, it is extremely difficult for us to find the necessary funds. However, if you consider that the toilets should be erected this year, you may proceed with their construction. You may, also, have the minor repairs done at a cost not exceeding $25.00.

Indian Commissioner MacKay was written yesterday with regard to your action in arranging repairs to the teachers' residence without receiving authority. In future, the Department will be unable to favourably consider unauthorized expenditures.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

B. T. Phillips, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Massett, B. C.

ENCL.
Dear Sir:-

May I have permission to have built two new toilets, (one for the Girls and one for Boys), the existing toilets are in very bad shape, and need removing to a new location.

The cost of each would be about $50.00; this would be with a step seat in each, one six inches lower than the other) with hinged covers when not in use. The building would be about 7' x 5', and about 7' high with a screen outside the building for entrance to toilets. The total cost with the holes dug would be about $100.00.

There is also other repairs in the School Sash Cords, Window Panes, desks to be repaired, and several boards on the outside of Building to be replaced by new lumber, this work would cost about $25.00.

This would make the Total cost of $125.00 for the Massett Indian Day School.

Extract from Inspector Barry's report on the Massett Indian Bay School inspected on May 30, 1940.

Since my last inspection a few windows have been made to open, but a number of the schoolroom windows are still nailed and it is impossible to open these for ventilation purposes. I should be glad if these windows be so arranged that they can be opened. The lock on the schoolroom building needs to be renewed or repaired. At the moment a Yale lock is used and as this must be kept in the locked position to keep the door from the outside closed there might be some danger in case of fire. The cost for a simple door lock, handle etc., is so small that I would recommend one be supplied and placed in position.
Ottawa,
June 17, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Reporting on his inspection of the Massett School on the 20th ultimo Inspector Barry writes as follows:

"Since my last inspection a few windows have been made to open, but a number of the schoolroom windows are still nailed and it is impossible to open these for ventilation purposes. I should be glad if these windows be so repaired that they can be opened. The lock on the schoolroom building needs to be renewed or repaired. At the moment a Yale lock is used and as this must be kept in the locked position to keep the door from the outside closed there might be some danger in case of fire. The cost for a simple door lock, handle etc. is so small that I would recommend one be supplied and placed in position."

The improvements recommended by the Inspector will involve no heavy expenditure and you may, therefore, arrange to have them carried out.

Yours truly,

Mr. B. T. Phillips,

Masset, B. C.

Dear Sir:

May I have authority to do the following:

Repairing at the Bennett Indian Day School and Teachers Residence.

I have attached herewith an itemized statement in duplicate for work necessary during the holidays.

The new brick porch and steps are included on the list, the cost is $25.00 more than was charged for last year's estimate, this is owing to stronger job being necessary using heavier lumber to support veranda and entrance. I should mention that the existing steps are in very bad condition and not worth replacing.

The front veranda at the teachers residence is also in need of repair requiring new floor and boards.

The wood shed at the back of teachers residence is in poor condition, and I have asked for a new one in the 1963-64 Estimates. In the meantime a lean-to shed next to the existing one is falling down, and I am asking for this to be pulled down and the side of wood shed boarded up so this year, the old toilet was in this old shed, and has to be filled up and cleaned away.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Major D.M. MacKay., Indian Commissioner for B.C. Vancouver, B.C.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated December 8th, 1942 giving authority for repairs etc, at the Massett Day school and teachers residence at the Massett I.R.

During the very cold spell here, a Valve burst under the wash basins at the school, so I took the opportunity while the weather was bad to replace the valve to save the school from being flooded, also at the teachers Residence the large wooden tank buckled on the bottom and let all the water out, so as not to inconvenience the teachers by having to carry all their water from a nearby spring, I had this repaired, putting in a new plank bottom, (this wood I had on hand) but I had to purchase Caulking, Putty nails etc for this job, the voucher for which payment is attached herewith, I also had to purchase a New Brass Valve for the School, which I hope meets with your approval.

With regard to labour, I have worked that in with the repairs authorized in your letter as above.

B.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON QUEEN CHARLOTTE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 1943.

At the Massett Reserve which I visited several times, I inspected the School, had a burst valve replaced, also had repairs made to a burst wooden tank at the teachers residence.

S.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C.,

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, enclosing resolution of the Massett Band, requesting an expenditure of $75.00 from their Band Funds to purchase a piano for the Massett Indian Day School.

I am advised by the Trusts Division that this expenditure cannot be approved from Band Funds.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Phillips letter of November 13th, 1942, advising that the Indians of Massett wish to purchase a second hand piano from Mr. D. Rutten of New Massett, in reply to which he was informed that it would be necessary for him to secure a resolution of the Band approving of the expenditure from their funds.

A Resolution dated the 27th ultimo has now been received and is enclosed herewith, requesting authority to expend $75.00 for the purchase of the instrument. I would approve of the application.

Enclosure.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Dear Sir:

On my recent visit to the Massett Indian Day School, a concert practice was in progress, and as mentioned in my last months School report (junior class) Mr Adams kindly loaned his Piano for their use.

As no doubt you are aware the Hiadas are very musical and this has been somewhat neglected owing to the lack of a Piano, however the Piano loaned by Mr Adams is only for the Christmas Concert, when it will be returned.

Mrs Read (the new teacher) informs me that the Piano is a real necessity, not only for musical lessons but marching in and out of school.

I have had the offer of a very fine Piano (player) Large Solid Oak, by Mason and Risch from a Mr D. Rutten of New Massett in good condition and tuned last year for $75.00. I have not been able to get the Council together to take this from the Band funds, but it was through the efforts of the Chief Councillor that Mr Adams loaned his piano, so I don't think there would be any objections to taking the above from the Band Funds.

Mr Rutten has kindly informed me he will hold the sale of the piano until I have word from you, as two other persons are willing to buy it. I forget to mention above that there are about 50 Rolls of Music goes with the Piano.

Yours faithfully,

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Ottawa, August 14, 1944.

AIR MAIL

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
Box 70, Vancouver, B. C.

I have your letter of the 10th instant,
with reference to supplies requested by Miss L. J.
Brunton, recently appointed teacher of the Massett
Indian Day School.

The Department is not prepared to authorize
Miss Brunton to purchase the books for either the
first or second year pupils or for Grades 3 and 4.
We have recently placed in stock, at the Government
Stationery Office, a large number of books which we
consider suitable for Indian schools, and we are
arranging to send a number of these to Massett.
I feel certain that these will be suitable.

You may authorize Miss Brunton to purchase
the kindergarten material at a cost of $7.50. She
may also purchase the articles shown on the attached
requisition for janitor supplies.

Encl.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Miss L. J. Brunton, formerly teacher at
the Citlakdomix Indian Day School and recently trans-
ferred to the Massett Indian Day School, has been in
communication with Mr. Indian Agent Phillips regard-
ing supplies at the school. She is of the opinion
that the supplies on hand are inadequate, and has
submitted the attached Requisitions to this office
in the hope that authority will be obtained in sufficient
time to enable her to purchase a number of the articles
personally and take them with her to Massett.

Page 1 of her Requisition requests a total of
30 books for 1st and 2nd year pupils at
an approximate cost of $20.00.

Kindergarten material as outlined at an
approximate cost of $7.50.

1 Doz. Supplementary Readers for Grades 3
and 4, and material for Upper class room
industrial or manual art, at an approximate
cost of $6.00.

Miss Brunton, in addition, has requested
6 Gramophone records of Marches, Games etc.,
for use in the school with her own Gramophone.

The items listed on Page 2 are self-explanatory,
and are the ones which Miss Brunton is anxious to select
personally.

Page 3 deals largely with Janitor supplies which,
apparently the previous teacher omitted to order.
Miss Brunton is a capable teacher with many years experience, and I am of the opinion the supplies asked for are necessary, and will be put to good use should the Department approve of the purchase of same. It would be appreciated if the Department would forward their decision by air mail so that purchase could be made locally by Miss Brunton prior to her departure for Massett.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

REPORT ON QUEEN CHARLOTTE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JULY, 1944.

At the Massett Reserve which I visited about seven times I inspected the painting of the School and building of the new wood shed, also inspected the teachery for repairs to be done during the holidays, I interviewed some of the Councillors at different times, the Chief being away fishing, so that a Council meeting was not held, I also visited several homes and the Cannery which is now canning Salmon, the clam operation this year was not so good, but this was due chiefly to bad weather, however the last two weeks around 5,000 cases of Salmon have been packed, and the supply of fish is plentiful, the majority of the men folk are out fishing in Area No. 2, and they are expecting a big run of humps in the Massett inlet very soon as they have been "spotted" outside North Island coming this way.

S.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent

October 13th, 1944.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

On my recent visit to the Massett Indian Day School, Miss Brunton requested that blinds for the bath school rooms be purchased to keep out the sun. I have not seen any blinds on these windows since I took over, but I do think they are necessary.

12 Blinds, 7' long x 3' Cloth measurement (these are stock size) would be required for both rooms; long cords could be purchased locally, as they will pull up from the bottom of the windows.

If the above meets with your approval, would you kindly have them sent from Vancouver, as I could not purchase same locally without having the merchant to order same for me.

B.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Phillips' letter of October 13th, in connection with window blinds required for both rooms at the Massett Indian Day Schools.

The windows of this building face directly south and blinds are no doubt necessary. These blinds may be secured in Vancouver at an approximate cost of $15.00, and I would recommend that authority be granted for this purchase.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.
